If you know about an assassin droid HK-47 from the Star Wars universe and you liked him and his twisted sense of sarcasm - you will love every second (err.. page?) of this book. If not, it doesn't really matter.

Not so much cynical sarcasm here as much as a healthy dose of android humor. I leave it up to you to decide how much exactly is a healthy dose. I had a blast.

So, the story:

People go to planetary exploration missions or just colonize those planets. People like doing that.

Indigenous life on those planets, however, generally doesn't. Indigenous life can be dangerous to the abovementioned human brave hearts.

To minimize the loss of life, The Company supplies explorers with security droids in addition to ships, supplies and general logistics.

On the other hand, to minimize the loss of money, explorers (mostly their employers) often sign up for the services of the lowest bidder in the security business.

If you haven't guessed it already, this is where our friendly droid comes in. All security units come with a Governor module installed which, among other things, prevents the android from going berserk and horribly murdering the exploration party he's tasked with protecting.

Of course, being made of cheap parts, his Governor module is also made of crap and allows the android to hack and override it. He doesn't horribly murder his exploration party (at least not yet :) but he does call himself MurderBot because of an event from his past. That knowledge would raise quite a few eyebrows if those pesky humans with their million questions only knew about it.

This is a good, action-packed story about a self-aware, socially-awkward android who just wants to be left alone. But that's not going to happen.

Oh, and body parts will fly left and right - both human and android alike.

I'm fairly certain I did not actually buy this book but it was given to me for review. Whoever you are, thank you for this gem! I'm putting the sequel high on my to-do list.

The story is gripping and narration just perfect. I shed a tear or two after realizing the book is barely over 3 hours long. I need a sequel!

Not 10 days after reading the book, I saw the tram in Amsterdam heading for Murderbot Station. I had to take a picture xD

2025 reread inspired by the streaming release. Still a quick, fun read that, thus far, is getting a good adaptation on streaming.

~

This was an excellent sci-fi novella told from a very unique point of view: a socially anxious, introverted murderbot (its term, not mine).

One way sci-fi stories, especially length constrained novellas, can fail is putting in too much exposition in building the world and not enough attention spent on getting a good story on the page. Wells avoids this by only relating what is important about the world as needed and not worrying about such things as: how did Humanity spread to the stars? Why are corporations so powerful? Why are ancient aliens artifacts and ruins so prized? Is the Simpsons still running?

By concentrating just on the ideas that are immediately important to the narrative Wells is able to tell a tight, exciting story that offers some glimpses into this future world without bogging down the thrust of the plot. Plus, leaving so many blank spaces in this universe offers her opportunities to explore them in later books.

As far as the story went it was tight, fast paced, action packed but held space for character introspection and development. Wells expertly balanced world building, character development, and story exceedingly well. I look forward to the future installments of this series.

I shouldn‚Äôt have liked this book. It‚Äôs very science fiction, with comms and feeds and HubSystems and MedSystems in nearly every paragraph, and as far as I can tell it also has planet-spanning cultures that are basically Modern American with one or two tweaks, and a generic aspect to the setting, seen for example in people‚Äôs consuming ‚Äúfood pacs‚Äù rather than any actual cuisine. Not only that, it‚Äôs definitely a space mystery/thriller; I find comparison to Firefly apt, and I stopped watching Firefly after the third episode (the horror one). This book, too, has a bit where we run around a station in which everyone has been brutally massacred and the killers are hiding‚Äîthough happily, it doesn‚Äôt lean into the horror elements.

And yet, I did thoroughly enjoy the novella, reading the whole book in one sitting. It has a sci-fi setting and a thriller plot, but it‚Äôs really a story about characters and relationships. Readers love Murderbot, which makes sense since it (awkward pronouns for a character but the ones used in the actual book! I read it as mostly male but have been interested to see others‚Äô differing interpretations) is quite endearing: socially awkward and mostly interested in retreating to private spaces to consume media, but programmed for heroism and increasingly invested in protecting its group of humans. That so many people are drawn so strongly to a character who hates human interaction, half-asses their job and just wants to watch trash TV perhaps speaks to cultural malaise, but here we are. And Murderbot has a great voice.

The scientists, meanwhile, are quite well-drawn given Bot‚Äôs disinterest in their appearances, lives or emotions‚Äîthe reader winds up with a solid sense of who these people are, and I found their dynamics as a group of friends engaging and believable. Insecure authors who feel the need to telegraph everything about everyone through their point-of-view character to the point that it borders on preternatural (‚ÄúI saw fear on his face, followed by determination, with a hint of smugness quickly concealed‚Ä¶.‚Äù) should read this book as a great example of how much about a character can be conveyed through their words and actions alone. I wound up liking the group of scientists quite a bit, especially the growing friendship between Bot and Dr. Mensah, which is lovely.

I do have a couple of criticisms that don‚Äôt simply boil down to disliking sci-fi. A couple of plot and setting elements are rather unconvincing. 
First, I have doubts about the viability of murderbots: of course it‚Äôs handy that they can easily regenerate from what for a human would be a catastrophic injury, while being programmed for selfless obedience. However, not only are they extremely expensive to create, but they apparently go rogue often enough that a group that wants to prevent questions being asked thinks that staging this as their cover story for murder is a good idea. Second, if what the evil survey group wants is exclusive rights to mine the planet without anyone else‚Äôs realizing it‚Äôs an archaeological site, secretly murdering the other survey groups seems extreme: have they considered just buying exclusive rights immediately and then evicting the others before they discover the truth? Why wouldn‚Äôt the political entities that bought the rights for the original surveys not send new survey groups if the first ones were killed by malfunctioning security bots that have nothing to do with the actual planet? And then, the ending perhaps wraps up more than such a short book calls for: 
Bot‚Äôs being owned by the corporation could have been milked for a lot more drama, which makes me wonder if Wells wrote this one without any guarantee there would be sequels, or if she just didn‚Äôt like that angle.

At any rate, I definitely did enjoy this, unusually for a novella; and the novella format probably helped, reducing the impact of elements I don‚Äôt ordinarily like. I plan to continue to the sequel, though I‚Äôd also love it if subsequent books were a bit less mystery/thriller than this.

Though thought to be devoid of a personality, this particular robot has a proclivity for soap operas (Sanctuary Moon) and solitude. 4.25 ‚≠êÔ∏è (amended in 24‚Äô) ‚Äî A fun, cheeky and somewhat prescient first book in the ‚ÄòMurderbot‚Äô Universe, that ultimately delivered on its premise well, abating any inevitable disparity between my personal experience versus expectations, whilst creating an intrigue that will stay with me until I get the opportunity to complete the series, hopefully in the near future, as it is abundantly clear to me now that this series not only has a place in the annals of modern Science Fiction, but in modern Literature as well.

I have been eagerly looking forward to commencing this series ‚Äî largely due to the incredible number of fellow readers I respect whom adore it ‚Äî In fact I‚Äôd say my interest was more solicitous, as once I held the hardback in my hand I had that tense feeling of wanting to clamp my hands around it strongly and devour the pages!

It‚Äôs fair to say that any time one has an intent for a book that is that veraciousness, things can never truly live up to such a promise. This was certainly the case here ‚Äî but this is no knock or disparagement ‚Äî I had hyped it up way way too much and I found the first 30 pages tough as a result.

But, as one of the beautiful things about literature we all cherish ‚Äî The novel took on a life of its own, shedding the scales of that ridiculously over-excitable hype of created in my head ‚Äî I soon began to settle into the very futuristic and bleak world of Murderbot & his human companions.

On a very distant planet, way out in the universe ‚Äî our protagonist is escorting a team of human scientists, whom have been tasked with scouring the surface of planets in order to gain as much scientific data as possible. The self labelled ‚Äòmurdebot‚Äô ‚Äî an android made up of the latest tech & software ‚Äî has hacked its own module, the module that ensures it is self-aware and not completely subservient to the humans as it should be ‚Äî creating a fun, engaging, easy to follow consciousness where the android is trying to discover who it really is and where it allegiances lie.

Then when a neighbouring mission goes bad, things get serious and it is here where All systems red goes from fun to ferociously-addictive, with twists and turns, black comedy, hopelessness and at its core the central message permeates every plot point, absorbing every paragraph due to it being the heartbeat of all human or non-human consciousness ‚Äî The search for self, identity, meaning and spirituality, the walk of life!

Murderbot ‚Äî as discovered this time round, that is read so well by Kevin Free & also brilliantly dramatised in a new late 2023 release ‚Äî thanks to its magnificent, one-of-a-kind self-consciousness and subsequent rationale, created by its hacking of its own system ‚Äî is truly a paradox and paradigm, that also has an insatiable appetite for killing ‚Äî this android is no robot! It‚Äôs self-deprecating, has a roller-coasting mental state that feels more human than any of the humans in the story, and becomes the near-perfect flawed protagonist you just cannot help but root for with legitimate passion and fervour ‚Äî Even upon a recent quick re-read before I tackle Book Two and beyond, it was paramountly evident that Martha Wells world of high-tech, space madness is of a certain genius that perhaps has yet to be fully appreciated for the creative brilliance it deserves.

What a fun SF novella. I bought this totally on a whim a few days ago when it's on sale since the synopsis and the reviews look promising. Different with other books languishing in my TBR shelf, I decided to read it right away (a record!) since the Kindle sample grabbed my attention.

It was so funny, if you like dry humour. The snarky, TV-series-bingewatcher 'SecUnit construct' with a penchant of saving its 'humans' because it actually cared. Well, just a bit. Not too much, since it did not even care who they were, or barely read his clients' personnel files (because it needed the storage space for its series collection LOL).

Of course, the Murderbot - as it preferred to call itself - had some other motives for its actions. Still very rational and it knew what it wanted. It is not a lovey dovey relationship with the humans, it even tried really hard not to communicate too much. As an introvert myself, I definitely symphatize with the bot. I too need time to recharge and be alone whenever I have had too many human interaction. And I too, obviously, am crazy about TV series. So, there you go. I have not read too many SF with a POV from a robot so this one is definitely memorable.

All in all, the novella is sharp, action-packed, has straightforward plot (because why not), no useless space for unnecessary world building, and of course, the characterization of the slightly depressed bot is marvelous - if you like Marvin from the Hitchhiker's novels, you'll like Murderbot. Kate Elliot mentioned in her blurb that All Systems Red is "clever, inventive, brutal when it needs to be, and compassionate without ever being sentimental." I could not agree more.

This novella has an airy tone that ends up delivering a punchy catharsis. The unnamed SecUnit that calls itself Murderbot is self-contained and wary while it hides that it disabled the governor unit that is supposed to control its actions. So it doesn't have to follow orders but it also doesn't want that fact discovered. So while the adventure/mystery story unfolds at a fast pace an undercurrent of autonomy and identity plays out in the background.

This undercurrent is highlighted by the group of humans Murderbot is working for/with. They're well-meaning and determined and lead by a woman with strong convictions and a quick mind. So when they discover that it is ungoverned, their reactions range from intrusively sympathetic to actively suspicious, giving the story scope (however slight) to explore those buried themes.

I thought at first that the action/mystery dominated that under-theme but I think Wells ends up using that to build the connection-through-adversity that forms the framework for the eventual resolution. Which delivers that punchy catharsis that brought me all the feelz.

So I'm giving this an unmitigated five stars, because I'm all about the feelz. But I'll note that the distance between underlying theme (autonomy and identity) and the story frame (action/mystery) in such a short work is enough that it'll be disconcerting to those who want more of one or the other. And I'll agree with Tadiana that the characterization for the rest of the crew is shallow. But I didn't care. I was all about the Murderbot/Mensah connection and that ending slew me.

Well that was a fun little diversion. And by little, I mean LITTLE! This is, hands down, the shortest book I've read all year. And also probably the easiest read I've done all year. Given my penchant for reading large and/or heady books, this one was pretty much a "blink and you'll miss it" deviation for me. It was also our book club pick following the behemoth that was Brandon Sanderson's The Way of Kings, and we chose it because it was an easy read, which we felt was necessary after wading through the 1000+ pages of TWoK.

So what did I think of All Systems Red? Well, it was...good. That's about the best I can come up with at the moment. I loved the idea of a rogue Security bot that hacked its own governor, stopped caring about the corporate mission, and decided to basically be a TV junkie. And the fact that it refers to itself as Murderbot was just priceless. But outside of those concepts, the story just didn't really move me like I hoped it would.

Part if this is, I'm sure, due to the brevity of the tale. There's not a lot of room for character arcs or deep plotting in a story this short. And I get it...it's not supposed to be a monster story. This is popcorn entertainment, and it achieves that goal rather well. But, that being said, I still was left feeling a little cold after reading All Systems Red. Nobody really gets any backstory or context, the people in the tale are essentially just random people who are assigned various archetypes and behaviors to stand out. I never got much of a visual of any of them. As for Murderbot, while admired the snarky way in which it narrated its tale, I still wanted to know more about it, and this never really came to pass.

Another thing that took away from my enjoyment is the way in which the narrative unfolds. I've read several books where the storytelling was...incidental at best. But All Systems Red takes the cake. Everything, and I mean EVERYTHING, was just kind of half-explained or defined. From the action to the locations to the characters themselves, nothing is written in much detail. In fact, the action scenes were comprised mostly of passages that read something like "I ran at it while shooting my projectile weapon. It was shooting at me at the same time. I got hit a few times, but I managed to find a vital area on my opponent and take it down." And...that's it. The problem with writing like this is it robs the story of any sense of drama or suspense. It's all so...casual. And that casual writing makes the narrative casual as well, which doesn't help to engage the reader as much.

Because this is a short novella, we jump from sequence to sequence pretty quickly, but even on things that I felt should have been given more weight, Martha Wells just kinda glosses over them. Not having read any of her other works, I can't say if this is just how she writes, or if she had to constrain herself to keep the story short & sweet. Again, I wanted more.

But it's not all bad! Murderbot is a fun narrator, and carries the first person POV tale quite well. I enjoyed the snark, the sarcasm, and the flippancy in which it viewed most situations it found itself in. I loved how anti-social Murderbot was, and how it really just wanted to be left alone to watch its video entertainment...aka soap operas.

The overall concept is also rather cool, but I feel that this could have been far more impactful as either a full-length novel or a larger novella. I wanted more heft with my tale, and I never received that. But I can see the potential here, and given that this is the first in a series of books, I think Martha Wells can certainly take this character in interesting directions. The ending of this one opens up all sorts of possibilities, and I'd like to see what is next for Murderbot.

It must figure out humans and how to act robot to keep his sentience a secret, not least because it had disabled certain modules in order to preserve its exercise of free will and a mortal‚Äôs sense of self-preservation amongst others. At the root, it now has to grapple with having opinions and feelings which necessitates understanding the nuances of human interactions including facial expressions and reading between the lines in order preserve its secret and later, to express his opinions and cooperate with humans to investigate possible breaches, criminal or fraudulent activities. In other words, Murderbot demonstrates both primary and secondary thinking by understanding learned behaviours, social conventions and personal goals as it deduces human and corporate motives.

Murderbot feels beyond basic feelings and emotions which extends to disgust, betrayal and even a fiddly form of empathy. Like an introvert, it prefers solitude because it gets overwhelmed or rather, irritated with social interactions, preferring to spend time doing what it wills. Its relationship with humans can be described as a form of reverse anthropomorphism‚Äîhumans don‚Äôt know how to categorise it and thus, the appropriate way to act around it while the murderbot tries to blend in with the humans as an android with hilarious results. Consequently, the book provides an opportunity to look into the human condition, facilitated by the juxtaposition of an augmented human character. Readers could then decide at what point a person or a robot becomes a machine and ceases to be human or vice versa, along with the ethical implications.

Content warnings include: violence and gore, murder, sentient robotic beings not having rights, anxiety and depression, scifi setting that's kind of a capitalist-corporation-lead dystopia.

Murderbot has become one of my favourite characters and comfort reads, as you can undoubtedly tell by me rereading this 4 to 5 times in the last three months.

There is Murderbot itself, a human-robot construct made out of both organic and robotic parts, who shut down the governor module that usually forces it to follow instructions and keep it from executing free will. It uses its freedom to keep doing its job while watching series on its memory storage. It doesn't really care about its job as a SecUnit, protecting humans who go on scientific explorations, and is quite content being ignored and seen as a robot, because when human interaction starts it gets complicated.

The plot of this novella is compelling. Things keep going wrong on the expedition, and the humans Murderbot works for are a bit different that the ones it usually encounters.

Murderbot's pessimism, its tendency towards anxiety and depression, mixed with the care and affection it develops towards who it begins to consider its humans, is endearing (even if it sounds like it's not), relateable, and often leads to comedic moments born from the first person narration.

The book is just so much fun to read, and while its plot is mostly self contained, it also acts as a wonderful setup for the rest of the series.
Highly, highly recommend this one!

The autopilot on the team's transport is sabotaged while they are exploring an anomaly on the survey map, leading to an investigation into who might have done it, and why.

Martha Wells‚Äô novella about a disaffected robot struggling with identity issues is like a set of Russian nesting dolls: there are stories within stories. It's an impressive accomplishment and Wells says more in 144 pages than most authors do in their 1,000-page trilogies.

The main story arc is a high-octane adventure about a sentient robot assigned to protect a group of scientists on their survey of a planet from sabotage, man-eating wildlife, and armed invaders from another company determined to take control of the planet at any cost. But the SecUnit assigned to protect the small survey group is a rogue agent with some serious psychological issues‚Ä¶MURDERBOT.

I could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.

Murderbot is the AI version of the sensitive loner in high school. The edgy introvert who would rather read Jack Kerouac than attend social events. Lightning fast and armed with energy cannons, Murderbot is a fighting machine that doesn‚Äôt want to fight. It‚Äôs a reluctant hero who would rather be left alone to watch media, but it feels a responsibility to get the hapless humans to safety. Like so many readers, I related to Murderbot from page one and loved its sarcastic sense of humor. Despite its preference for mainlining galactic soap operas, there are plenty of gun fights and last-minute rescues for readers who want a fun adventure story.

I knew I could kill everyone on the hopper, even with a blown hip joint and one working arm. So I grabbed the hand weapon on the seat, turned it toward my chest, and pulled the trigger.

The second story arc is about free will, personhood, and the future of AI. SecUnits like Murderbot are leased out by their corporate owners to protect human clients; they are considered property rather than people. While robots can be citizens in some territories outside corporate space, they are second-class citizens at best who are required to have human guardians. Sentience and the desire for self-determination are not sufficient for bots to be free or equal to humans. The author contrasts Murderbot‚Äôs experience with Gurathin, a human cyborg on the survey team. While both Murderbot and Gurathin are part organic and part machine, Gurathin is a citizen with all the attendant rights, simply because he was born human. Murderbot was built in a lab, so it despite its intelligence, cloned human tissue, and the ability to have feelings, it is considered a machine no different than a PC. Murderbot is trying to decide who it wants to be and how it wants to live in a society that doesn't allow it to make either of those decisions.

It‚Äôs wrong to think of a construct as half bot, half human. That makes it sound like the halves are discrete‚Ä¶as opposed to the reality, which was that I was one whole confused entity.

Finally, and least developed, is the story arc about the future of humanity after we colonize space. Given the page limits of a novella, Wells just sketches in brief outlines of humanity and governance across various worlds. The book takes place in the Corporate Rim, where multi-planet companies rule and money is the only thing that matters. Murderbot blandly notes that the company that leased it to the survey group would certainly take bribes from an opposing survey group and says the only reason the company wouldn‚Äôt conspire to murder its clients is because the death payouts would be too high. Meanwhile, the survey group is from a democratic planet called Perseverance in non-corporate space, which values human rights, decency, and the rule of law. Bots have limited rights under those laws, and the survey group wants Murderbot to return with them to their liberal planet. Basically, you have unchecked capitalism vs. democratic socialism as co-existing philosophies in space, although it's unclear how that happened.

I‚Äôm docking half a star because I enjoy complex world-building (e.g., John Scalzi) and would have loved to read more about the different star systems. I also felt that most of the secondary characters were underdeveloped. I wish Wells had written a full-length novel that fleshed out the characters, especially Mensah, the courageous and compassionate team leader who bonds most closely with Murderbot. But these are mere quibbles; the book is fantastic and I have already started reading the next novella in the series.

4.5 heartwarming stars.

In a space-faring future dominated by corporate greed, planetary missions must be accompanied by Security Units rented from the Company. Murderbot (it refers to itself as such, but never out loud) is a Sec Unit - a half human, half robot construct - who's hacked its own Governor Module and has gained free will. However, instead of slaughtering its human overlords, Murderbot has decided to keep its day-job guarding humans, and streams a boatload of TV shows in its downtime.

Murderbot is on a standard assignment, acting as security for a research team from the Preservation Alliance, lead by Dr. Mensa. Distrustful of humans, Murderbot just wants to do its job and watch The Rise and Fall of Sanctuary Moon for the millionth time. But, when a neighboring mission goes mysteriously dark, its up to Murderbot and its humans to figure out the truth.

All Systems Red is a fabulous first-installment in what is now one of my favorite series. Thanks, I'm obsessed.

Murderbot is one of my all-time favorite characters. How could I not love this anti-social, grumpy, achingly sentimental human-robot construct? Not only is Murderbot hilarious - its reluctance to do anything but stream TV shows and be away from humans was so relatable - there's also a wounded, surprisingly vulnerable aspect to Murderbot's personality. Most humans see Sec Units as murderous androids that are little more than weapons, but that's far from true. They are essentially sentient humanoid constructs that are enslaved by humanity, and mistreatment of androids within the Corporation Rim is a sad reality. Murderbot does not trust humans, because it knows the levels of cruelty and ignorance humans are capable of.

However, Murderbot finds the current group of human its protecting to be...different. And wouldn't you know it, Murderbot is starting to care about them.



‚ÄúThey were all so nice and it was just excruciating. I was never taking off the helmet again. I can't do even the half-assed version of this stupid job if I have to talk to humans.‚Äù



I loved Murderbot's relationships with its new clients so much, and I thoroughly enjoyed the human characters: Dr. Mensa, Ratthi, Pin-Lee, Arada, Overse, Volescu, Bharadwaj, and even Gurathin were all wonderful, and I loved witnessing their growing fondness of Murderbot. My heart is full to bursting.

The mystery had me on the edge of my seat, I cared so very deeply for Murderbot and its clients, and I had such a fun time reading from Murderbot's perspective. Its narration is wholly distinct, dry, witty, and endearingly awkward and pessimistic. I just love Murderbot, okay? I want to be Murderbot's friend, even though I know it'd want nothing to do with me since I'm a human. But...AH. I LOVE THIS SERIES.



‚ÄúIt‚Äôs wrong to think of a construct as half bot, half human. It makes it sound like the halves are discrete, like the bot half should want to obey orders and do its job and the human half should want to protect itself and get the hell out of here. As opposed to the reality, which was that I was one whole confused entity, with no idea what I wanted to do. What I should do. What I needed to do.‚Äù



If you haven't noticed, I'm a big fan of this series. If you haven't read All Systems Red, do yourself a favor and pick this up on audio. The narrator perfectly captures Murderbot's voice, and they're so enjoyable to listen to!

I started listening to All Systems Red on Scribd with the hopes of passing some time listening to something fun and simple while doing kitchen chores. Boy, was I wrong. I ended up not only cleaning the kitchen, reorganizing the pantry, fridge, cooking dinner, and meals for the next day in the hopes of listening to as much of this as possible before having to put it away for the night. It is compulsive and addictive read. Once you start reading it, it is so short and exciting you will not want to stop till you get to the end.

All Systems Red is a perfect and tidy story. When I say tidy, it isn't derogatory. Novellas have to get a lot done in a short amount of time. The author needs to convey thought, history, emotion, narrative, and plot progression. So all of the choices the author makes need to be concise and tidy. In Martha Wells, All Sytems Red, she created an exceptional character in Murderbot, Murderbot being the name he calls himself. He is cynical, confused, and courageous but more than anything, Murderbot has very human emotions. This character works quite well within the context of a novella because the reading audience has a cultural dialog regarding machines with human emotions, i.e., The Terminator. There isn't a lot of groundwork to be laid, we already have a feel for what this scenario could look like. Murderbot is an artificial life form with organic components, and these components work in tandem with its artificial ones to create the perfect killing machine.

How life works for the Murderbot is that he is deployed on contract through his host company, The Company. In the first installment of the quadrilogy of short stories, Murderbot is protecting and defending a group of scientists and geographers on an inhospitable planet. Murderbot hacks his mainframe to start making independent choices aside from is company programming. Most of his decisions consist of which type of soap opera to watch on the entertainment channels available at his outpost. However, when another outpost on the same planet gets attacked, Murderbot needs to step in to protect the scientists that he has become attached to. What plays out over the brief story is exciting scenes, great dialog (both internal and external), and an excellent plot jump to the next novella. I loved this, and it is easily understood why the author received so many well-deserved accolades. It is funny and enjoyable.

This book belongs to one of my favorite SF sub-genres - sentient AI. Scientists and philosophers should have come up with better answers for the problem of conscious AI at least a decade ago, but well, here we are. In the domains of SF. Again.

Is organicity a necessary and sufficient condition for consciousness? Now Cartesian dualism will give you a solid no and I agree, but when it comes to AI, I've heard people arguing that AI cannot be 'conscious' because the notion of 'I' necessitates cognitive acts that are conscious and not merely computational. I'll ignore the dangers of such a reduction for now because murderbot, our protagonist from this series, has hacked their governer module. Their (Really, they have an organic bodysuit but they don't seem to think much of it and they never state their preferred pronouns in this book, I doubt they have one) acts are not merely computational.

Murderbot has very human traits - social awkwardness, rage, passivity, compassion and a weird possessiveness. But I'm also wary of the idea that anything alien must correspond to human-ness in order to ascribe a notion of subjectivity to it, as though consciousness is merely a human attribute. And this is where Becky Chambers does really well, I love how she writes about AI and alien species. With this author, I'm still a little cautious.

However, it was very enjoyable and light. I'm fairly confident I'll read the rest of the series. Probably over the next few weekends when I need a break from non-fiction.

This short science fiction book is a gem. I can understand how this could be considered a young adult book. The plot is straight-forward and a bit space-operish. The main character's psychology is what makes it a fascinating novella for adults.

The story is told in the first person by the protagonist, self-named Murderbot. He/she is a robot. They were made as a security guard. (Should I use They/Them for Murderbot? Or only with 100% humans? I'm new to using the new pronoun methodology.) There are three types of beings in this world: humans, augmented humans (like the Million Dollar Man), and robots. The robots are primarily mechanical but still include many human parts. Maybe this is why Murderbot so easily became sentient when they hacked their governor component.

Before Murderbot became self-aware they were ordered to kill many humans and now feels bad about it. Not that Murderbot likes humans. They'd rather sit in the cargo hold watching television than mingling with humans. If they are forced to communicate face-to-face with a human they prefer doing it with their face shield down; or turn facing into a corner to avoid eye contact.

The narrative is very funny. Murderbot thinks most humans are dimwits. They use self-depreciating humor too. If you think the astronauts' inner dialog in Project Hail Mary and The Martian by Andy Weir is funny you probably will find this humorous too.

I will be re-reading this sometime for pure pleasure.

A confession, it took me 6+ months to complete this novella, not because I didn‚Äôt like it, but solely because I wanted to only commence the second instalment, immediately following the final chapter, because well I can‚Äôt quite recall but likely as I intended to commence the follow-up almost immediately & wanted it to flow on perhaps ‚Äî I digress ‚Äî and in classic book-addict style, in doing this I allowed 50 other books to fit in-between.. oh dear!

In ‚ÄúAll Systems Red", Wells yields a wildly original & quite remarkable piece of introspective, dramatically portrayed science fiction that manages to masterfully blend the human and the mechanical, in every sense of the words, by expertly crafting a unique, taut, considered narrative that keeps readers engaged, gripped and also somehow existentially ponderous, from the poignant beginning to the acutely non-complex, end. Earning a solid 4.5 ‚≠êÔ∏è rating thanks to the aforementioned narrative, this novella is an extremely economically efficient, sharp-punching-black-eye-shining gem in the world of speculative fiction, science fiction, space opera & to be honest, fiction full-stop. But the narrative isn‚Äôt the only success here.

Wells introduces us to a world where artificial constructs, known as "SecUnits," are non-autonomously tasked with security and protection, for their human clients. However, the protagonist here ‚Äî Murderbot ‚Äî is not your typical SecUnit, thanks to some ‚Äî very cleverly designed ‚Äî software flaws that remove his inability to use free-will. With a wry sense of humor, introspective tendencies, and a secret desire for freedom, Murderbot truly transcends the typical, monotonous robot archetype to develop into a loveably intelligent, moving & deeply relatable character. It is through Murderbot's narrative voice that we explore themes of identity, autonomy, and the blurred lines between human and machine.

The novella's pacing is close to impeccable. Wells keeps the tension riotously taut, using concise prose that effortlessly carries the reader through the story. The action sequences are adrenaline-fueled, but what truly sets "All Systems Red" apart is its ability to balance intense moments with moments of quiet reflection. Murderbot's internal struggles and musings on the nature of freedom add depth to the story, elevating it beyond a mere action-packed adventure.

The world-building in "All Systems Red" is another standout aspect. The author crafts a richly detailed future where corporate interests clash with the desire for knowledge and exploration. The various planets and habitats are vividly described, immersing the reader in a universe that feels both familiar and alien. Wells also delves into the complexities of interstellar politics and the ethical dilemmas posed by advanced AI, adding layers of depth to the narrative.

One of the novella's strengths lies in its character dynamics. Murderbot's interactions with its human clients, particularly with the scientist Dr. Mensah, are a highlight of the story. The evolving relationships and the growth of trust between these characters are beautifully portrayed. It's a testament to Martha Wells & I cannot wait to delve further into the speculative world of Murderbot & it‚Äôs undoubtedly entertaining, violently fascinating tales!

This book was captivating from the first sentence


"I could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites..."


I'm a big fan of Martha Well's Books of the Raksura series (The Cloud Roads) so it took a while to build up the courage to read her more acclaimed Murderbot novella. All that hesitation for naught! This book is so different and it is so good

Murderbot is a Security Unit that is contractually added to research team's expeditions. It is owned by a parent company and rented out, where it's in charge of making sure scientists don't get eaten by fauna in the field. Unfortunately the company, like irl companies, is cheap as hell and leaves people on the field with faulty equipment. Murderbot itself has fallen victim to this before so on its newest mission, hacks its own regulatory module to avoid a repeat of the past.

The novella is full of worldbuilding, and despite the book's small size Wells does a really good job at making this universe come to life.

The star here is Murderbot. It is a hilarious, awkward, relatable character, and the ethics of having a sentient, mixed organic Unit like Murderbot contractually trapped under employers for its entire existence is noted, but not dragged out like you normally deal with these types of scifi

Love love love

Also at one point I put the book down and screamed because I realized:
Books of the Raksura: MC is a creature who is aro and finds acceptance with his long lost people
Murderbot Diaries: MC is a creature who is ace and finds acceptance with a species not its own

In short: I love them your honor

Sometime in the unspecified distant future, mankind and augmented mankind will be colonizing exoplanets by the bucket load. A required presence on these missions is one or more SecUnits, a cyborg programmed to keep humans from getting eaten by sandworms or whatever.

This is the first in a series of four novellas (and a forthcoming novel) about one SecUnit who has surreptitiously hacked its operating system and become a free agent. Mostly this means watching downloaded episodes of a soap opera called Sanctuary Moon and pretending it doesn't care about the human crew on its latest mission.

This SecUnit calls itself Murderbot, and Murderbot is adorable (I also hate calling Murderbot it, but it/they/Murderbot doesn't have a gender or else then it would be working in the sex trade.)

This story opens with a bang when an exploratory science team is almost eaten by a graboid--I'm convinced outer space is full of giant killer worms--and Murderbot rushes to the rescue. What follows is a tightly plotted but somehow heartwarming tale of espionage! Murder! Sanctuary Moon!

I really enjoyed this. It was three stars until near the end, when I realized I loved the characters (especially Murderbot) and didn't want it to end. It was funny and smart. And it broke the bad luck streak I've had with Tor novellas (I know this makes me a monster, but I could not get into Every Heart a Doorway or River of Teeth.)

Also, interesting trivia: the future is polyamorous.

I'll definitely be reading more of these.

I'm coming to realize that I really really love novellas. They are a perfect gauge for author's talent and writing capabilities, for their ability to weave a story in so few words. I knew that Brandon Sanderson was a master of novellas (in my opinion, of course), but so apparently is Martha Wells.

The reader doesn't need any more details than already given because the reader gets what MurderBot gets. The MurderBot powers down, the reader feels powered down. When MurderBot cares - the reader cares. When shit goes down, well then shit just goes down.

Cannot wait to pick up the next one, because what is with that ending??

From the beginning, I was hooked. Murderbot is owned by a company and is sent out as the security bot for a scientific exploration group on a new planet. They are there to determine if they want to buy into the shares for the planet by testing the natural resources available. It's not long before Murderbot is working hard to keep his little herd of scientists safe from someone bent on sabotaging and maybe killing off their stranded group before the date the company comes back to pick them up. Murderbot is fully in command of himself due to a faulty command module and he has to trick everyone into thinking that all systems are normal.

The wry wit of Murderbot (he did have a mass killing under his belt so why not), his non-human way of looking at things, his addiction and binge-watching of human entertainment vids, and the uncertainty this lethal being has around feelings and acts of goodness from humans who generally treat him like equipment makes for an engaging story.

I found it a great blend of character-driven with action plotting. It was a quick read, but very developed. The stranded with someone out to get them for unknown reasons was a great backdrop to see Murderbot and the isolated scientists interact and learn to work together. I liked that it ended leaving things wide open for what comes next even while wrapping up this first exciting chapter in the story.

Well that was unexpected.

I knew nothing about All Systems Red when I browsed my way to it on Audible, but it's cover art looked okay (albeit a little too polished), it had a sweet little blurb, and it was the perfect length to off-set the monster long books to which I was already listening, so I gave it a shot. Damn glad I did.

All Systems Red is a tasty little morsel that dives straight in to what it means to be human through the question of the autonomy of artificial beings. We're thrown into the first person perspective of Murderbot, a security bot who has hacked out its governing system and made itself a free agent. But Martha Wells doesn't retread old Pinocchio-Replicants-Data territory. Instead, she gives us a being easily distracted by bad TV, a being who finds itself empathizing with its comrades without obsessing over the meaning of it all, a being with clear likes and dislikes, a being able to pity and be pitied, a being much like us. Murderbot just wants to live without having to worry about the deletion of memories, a return to enslavement or the loss of choice. It's a pretty simple being, and a likeable one too.

Martha Wells is tackling one of the future's great ethical conundrums here, and she does it while spinning a kick ass adventure -- not too in-depth, not too intense, just right. Fingers crossed that the series will just get better and better.

Well, I'm not going to decide now. MAAAAYBEEE I will be in the mood to do so. Maybe not. So in the meantime, I can say that I read this. I loved Murderbot.

/End message.

Review of All Systems Red by Martha Wells
‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ

Let me just say it: All Systems Red is the introverted, sarcastic, secretly-caring AI murder machine I didn‚Äôt know I needed in my life.

This novella launches the Murderbot Diaries with a sharp elbow to the ribs of typical sci-fi and a quietly broken heart under all the armor plating. Our protagonist‚ÄîMurderbot, a SecUnit with hacked programming and a deep desire to be left alone to binge-watch serial dramas‚Äîhas major antisocial vibes, a dry-as-space-dust sense of humor, and the most reluctant hero energy since Han Solo got dragged into the Rebellion.

Murderbot doesn‚Äôt want to save anyone. It wants to curl up in a cargo container, watch its shows, and avoid eye contact with humans. But, alas, humans are fragile meatbags with feelings, and they keep trying to include it in things. Ugh.

But here‚Äôs the twist: the more the crew treats Murderbot like a person instead of a weapon, the more we see just how human this bot really is‚Äîfull of anxiety, trauma, and an identity crisis buried under layers of sarcasm and armor. And all of it is told in Murderbot‚Äôs first-person narration, which is brilliantly hilarious, often touching, and incredibly relatable to anyone who‚Äôs ever felt awkward at a group meeting.

The plot? Tight and tense. Sabotage, mystery, dead survey teams, and corporate nastiness in space‚Äîall classic ingredients, but served up fresh thanks to the voice guiding us through it.
The pacing? Lightning-fast. Like Murderbot when someone suggests they join a team-building exercise.
The emotional depth? Shockingly deep for a novella about a semi-killer robot that watches space soaps.

In short, All Systems Red is like if Marvin the Paranoid Android got therapy and a plasma cannon. It‚Äôs a story about identity, autonomy, and finding yourself‚Äîeven if you‚Äôre a rogue security unit with no time for your feelings, thank you very much.

Why will I continue the series?
Because:
‚úîÔ∏è AI with anxiety and attitude? Check.
‚úîÔ∏è Humor that actually made me laugh out loud? Check.
‚úîÔ∏è A genuinely compelling plot with heart and tension? Check.
‚úîÔ∏è Murderbot. Just‚Ä¶ Murderbot.

Would recommend to:

Sci-fi fans

Introverts

People with anxiety

Anyone who‚Äôs ever whispered ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to be perceived‚Äù and then saved the day anyway

Remember all those shows you‚Äôve been avoiding, because the dialogue, written by the same two people, sounds like the verbal equivalent of slapstick? Would you like that speech turd repackaged as the protagonist‚Äôs inner monologue, and labelled as "humour"?

Murderbot is not what you might expect. When It‚Äôs not regurgitating comedy lines from the shows it binge-watches, Murderbot‚Äôs narration consists of near-constant introspection into Its own emotions, or, alternatively, speculation on what other people might be feeling.

This is a pity, because if I wanted to read a book about a middle-aged, over-emotional divorcee who hits the sauce on most evenings, then tearfully ponders the feelings of her estranged children, I wouldn‚Äôt have picked up a science-fiction book about a cyborg.

Science-fiction is one of the most difficult genres to write. It‚Äôs prohibitively difficult. You need vast scientific and technical knowledge, combined with artistic creativity, and a talent for writing. This is, statistically speaking, an extremely rare combination in humans.

And I cannot beat about the bush ‚Äì for a science-fiction novel, the author does not treat us to many descriptions of science or technology. In fact, you get the impression, she‚Äôs being purposefully vague. Murderbot uses a ‚Äúbig gun.‚Äù It cures Its wounds with a ‚Äúsealant.‚Äù And whether Martha Wells likes it or not, the expression ‚Äúmy organic parts‚Äù sounds like a Victorian Era euphemism for genitals.

To analyse a situation, Murderbot has to watch hours of Its own camera footage in real time. Instead of using any kind of threat modelling, Murderbot judges mission outcomes by how depressed It feels, the migrations of birds in the sky, and shamanic mushrooms.


The book‚Äôs gravest mistake, however, is starting the action after Murderbot‚Äôs self-liberation from its ‚Äúgovernor module.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a reason why Cinderella does not begin with Cinderella already being the princess; parading round the castle in silk taffeta; telling the reader occasional anecdotes of how bad she used to have it with her evil step-mother. A transformation is only appreciated when there‚Äôs little assurance of it; when we walk with our character in darkness, without any certain knowledge that things might change. When we face terror and doubt, and derision; when we recoil in revulsion at Murderbot‚Äôs carnage; when we watch Murderbot kill ‚Äì only then can we begin to appreciate the fact that It stops killing.

If you mean to start in medias res, and you mean business, start in the dark days. Don‚Äôt cheapen your own victory. No prequel can ever absolve the sins of the first book.


All Systems Red makes very little attempt to bring the reader any intellectual satisfaction. The story is simplistic, na√Øve, and rushed to the complete abandonment of character development. The scenes seem cut prematurely. It‚Äôs a summary, more than anything ‚Äì a rushed summary of an idea, with dialogue added on top. The science is non-existent, the fiction is a quandary I lay at the feet of relativity.

I‚Äôm kidding. It‚Äôs bad.
The author uses words like ‚Äúbird-thing.‚Äù

And that is why I recommend reading this book in no other manner, than with Ramblin‚Äô Gamblin‚Äô Man by Bob Seger, playing on full blast. I think it improves the experience by 20%.

I COULD HAVE BECOME a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don‚Äôt know, a little under 35,000 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.

Rating: Absolutely Loved It (potential for all-time favorite rating for sure)

How could I NOT fall in love with Murderbot with an opening like that???

Should I be concerned with how much I relate to a human-robot construct who sees their sole purpose for existence to murder? Probably. Am I really that concerned? NO!

Poor Murderbot just wants to be left alone to consume their various forms of media in peace, and the humans in their charge just keep narrowly escaping death and then trying to do weird and annoying things like TALK to them about FEELINGS. BUT WHY!? I felt like Murderbot and I could be the same person at times: the social anxiety, the extreme introvertedness, the cynical and sarcastic inner monologue. This is the most I have related to a main character since House in the Cerulean Sea. I swear some of Murderbot's lines were things I have expressed to friends at one time or another.

Okay, done gushing, I will try to move to a more cohesive review mind now. Novellas are really hit or miss for me, so I was somewhat apprehensive going into this one. The world building and the characters other than Murderbot are not super well defined, but I didn't find that it took away from the story. I was primarily focused on Murderbot and getting to know them better. I think that if Murderbot isn't a character that you connect with, or someone whose humor you find to your taste, then this won't be that big of a hit with you.

Ultimately the storyline and the setting were somewhat unremarkable, but they were made fun and entertaining by the presence of our friend Murderbot. Original Review:

As it says in the blurb, Murderbot hacked its governor module‚Äîfor those not mechanically inclined, think of it as a choke collar. While it follows its orders so that it isn't discovered and risk getting scrapped, it has the freedom to ignore commands it doesn't want to carry out or just pretend to carry them out. It doesn't want to talk about its feelings or hang out with the human crew. It wants to spend as much free time as possible watching thousands of hours of entertainment media it downloaded. Introverts everywhere will identify with Murderbot and quite possibly want its weapons complement to keep pesky annoyances at bay.

The novella is told entirely from Murderbot's POV, but it is perceptive enough to gauge others' reactions to it. And the internal dialogue is full of plenty biting humor that I guffawed audibly several times, eliciting curious inquiries from my family.

Being part-organic, Murderbot isn't invincible either. Although the company has built them to be self-repairing, they are disposable to some extent. Murderbot's vulnerability is made obvious to the reader from the outset. But despite this, Murderbot doesn't hesitate to throw itself into danger. Is its programming overriding self-preservation, or does it actually have a smidge of empathy for the humans it's assigned to protect? That's up to the reader to figure out.

Highly enjoyable.

Jan 2020:
At this point in my life, it's rare for me to re-read a book as there's so much that I haven't read that it makes more sense to journey through those undiscovered worlds. But the day after Christmas I found myself in a hotel room in Maine where my kindle couldn't talk to the wireless network. A new book I'd intended to read apparently hadn't downloaded and thus couldn't update. I decided to re-read a book I had on hand and, considering the circumstances, I opted to hang out with Murderbot. Later on, I managed to find a book in the ransacked remnants of the book section of some OddLots-style store and switched to that. I set Murderbot aside.

And then my dad died on New Year's Eve.

I was on a plane New Year's Day to travel to my parents' house. Just sitting there with nothing to do, I desperately needed a distraction from my grief. And just as Murderbot preferred to hide from humans with its visor opaque on its helmet, I needed the same. So I picked up right where I left off.

It's not that I found comfort in words of wisdom from the author. It's not that this was some big revenge fantasy‚Äîthere was no one to take revenge upon for my father's death. It's that the story was familiar, short, pure escapism, and had a main character that I could relate to: an introvert that just wanted to be left alone, didn't want to hang out making small talk, and certainly didn't want to discuss its feelings.

You can read into that any way you want.

Murderbot is a sarcastic, socially awkward joy. I can't remember the last protagonist I read who had such a distinct voice; dry and grumpy but also resolutely loyal and quietly kind. Wells manages to transmit an incredible complexity of emotion below Murderbot's prickly exterior; doggedly protecting its humans and monologuing about free will while all the while reminding us it really just wants to be watching its TV show right now. Murderbot is a love letter to all of us who don't always have the energy, the patience, or, let's face it, the passion for social interaction.

Plot-wise, this novel does an incredible job of packing a compelling, well-paced story into a neat 144 pages. The corporate colonization of the universe through various arms of "The Company" is an interesting, insidious framework that makes teases at a broader world, though Wells does an excellent job of keeping the focus on Murderbot and the Preservation crew. Though the star of the story is unquestionably Murderbot there is a surprisingly broad (and by this I mean 5+) cast of main supporting characters, and to my pleasant surprise I felt like I had a good sense of all of them by the conclusion of the novella. I cannot stress how difficult this is to do in such a short span, especially when the POV spotlight is elsewhere.

For a book that is equally about autonomy and the evils of capitalism as it is the sheer agony of eye contact, All Systems Red manages to be a perfectly charming, breezy read. I've truly never wanted to hug a character more who would NOT appreciate my doing so. I could read a hundred Murderbot novellas and fall in love a little more each time.

Original review:

This review originally appeared over at Booknest.eu!

Copy borrowed from my local library. Support libraries, folks!

While browsing through the rows of books in English in the Swedish library I frequent, I came across Martha Wells‚Äô All Systems Red, a novella whose cover I dimly recalled seeing years before on Tor.com. I looked through my To-Read list and ‚Äì surprise! ‚Äì this one was nowhere near it‚Ä¶as if that would stop me. I grabbed it, stole away Ada Palmer‚Äôs Too Like the Lightning as well, in case someone thought this thin novella too conspicuous. Long live sci-fi!

By the end of the night, I‚Äôd read through the first of these titles with barely any effort.

All Systems Red offers a fun story from the point of view of an anxiety-riddled robot with several biological components and a touch of misanthropy: ‚ÄúI liked the imaginary people on the entertainment feed way more than I liked real ones, but you can‚Äôt have one without the other‚Äù. This SecUnit calls itself Murderbot and seeks to avoid all direct interactions with its human wards, interested only in watching the tv, music and game programmes on entertainment channels. If this isn‚Äôt enough to make the Murderbot relatable, I don‚Äôt know what will.

Stuck on a planet with a band of scientists performing geological studies, our protagonist hopes to avoid any sort of excitement; unfortunately for him, this is a sci-fi novella intent on putting Murderbot on the spot and testing its mettle! A few action scenes are only to be expected ‚Äì and they were well handled and entertaining.

The prose is serviceable ‚Äì not quite excellent, but it doesn‚Äôt need to be. There‚Äôs plenty of great interactions, the dialogue never tends towards the heavily expositional and the personalities of all the scientists, led by team leader Mensah, shined through. Oh, and the humour? Golden: ‚ÄúYes, talk to Murderbot about its feelings. The idea was so painful I dropped to 97 percent efficiency. I‚Äôd rather climb back into Hostile One‚Äôs mouth.‚Äù

In terms of antagonists, the architects behind our protagonist‚Äôs woes don‚Äôt make for anything especially memorable; they‚Äôre rather archetypal, presenting rather the depths to which human greed tends to go when a group of people goes off the deep end. It works well and keeps our SecUnit and his group of scientists on their toes and pushing themselves as hard as they can to survive.

Once embroiled in a crisis, Murderbot is willing to put its life on the line for the band of humans it has been tasked with protecting ‚Äì despite it hacking its governance module. The same module that allows anyone who‚Äôs signed a deal with the Company ‚Äì like the scientists ‚Äì to command Murderbot. By working to save Mensah and the rest of her team from a shadowy enemy, then, Murderbot is exercising its free will ‚Äì and this is at the heart of what‚Äôs examined in Wells‚Äô novel. The question is one of freedom and compassion and examination of the self, and the text goes a long way in showing how Murderbot exercises all three.

My score for All Systems Red is a 4/5. This is a legitimately enjoyable adventure in a science fiction setting with plenty of good zingers and a socially awkward Robocop ‚Äì what‚Äôs not to love?! I‚Äôm looking forward to reading more about Murderbot in the future! I‚Äôll definitely be picking up his story when I‚Äôm next in my local library!

I almost really liked this book.

Right off the bat, it was clear Murderbot's personality was what will keep the reader engaged, and it mostly managed to do that. The first chapter is hilarious, and the depiction of Murderbot as the incarnation of that voice in our head that says: "I wish everyone would die and leave me alone, but I can't deal with that so I'll just watch TV instead" is spot on, and is relatable in a wonderfully morbid way.

Trouble comes on three fronts: one, Murderbot has a story arc that doesn't make sense. Two, everything besides Murderbot is completely uninteresting. Three, the writing is... strange.

The first: Murderbot was a wonderfully intriguing character at the beginning, but that was because it seemed like it truly was a depressed killing machine. Very quickly it turns out that it cares tremendously about human beings and would readily risk its life to save strangers.
Another point is the ending, which comes out of nowhere: 
after telling us for the entire book that it wants nothing other than to be left alone and watch TV, it suddenly decides to become independent and travel to an unknown destination, saying how it wants to be free and not follow anyone.

The second: the story and characters are significantly lacking. The plot is the most generic possible, the characters are (almost) all flat. It partly works because this is how Murderbot sees the world, as it doesn't pay much attention to people. But I, the reader, do care. Many choices and actions make little sense, the antagonists are behind the scenes for the entire book until they appear for five minutes and are quickly dealt with (in a way that doesn't make sense). We are told about the characters' relationship status (a loner with a crush, a lesbian couple, one in a four way marriage, one in a three way marriage, etc), but are told nothing else about their lives. Murderbot claims to not care at all about sex, but that's the only thing it tells us about its coworkers.

The third: the writing style is strange to me (it might be more about me than the book, as I'm not a native english speaker).
The descriptions sometimes fail to take into account things the author knows but the reader doesn't. For example: Murderbot attacks two enemies, describing how it took them by surprise and shot them until they stopped moving. Then it describes where and how much it got shot itself. Then it describes how just before the fight had started, it sent a few miniature drones to crash against the enemies. What's with the strange order of events? It made me imagine how the scene went, then forced me to change it a moment later. Most of the action scenes in the book are weirdly described.
This appears in several other places too, where the author apparently lost track of what the reader knows and doesn't know, and it made for an uncomfortable reading.

One additional point, this time about the genre: the sci-fi elements are severely underutilized and unexplored, which feels like a waste. There is not a single sci-fi element here that you haven't already seen a million times before.

An exciting start to a series of primarily novellas, I‚Äôm intrigued to see where it‚Äôs headed next.

Wells sets the scene and explains not only the world but our protagonist very quickly. There‚Äôs action, violence, and danger from the beginning, and we‚Äôre left to piece everything together on the fly. This is done so well that I was fully on board much sooner than usual for a sci-fi novel. There are no hurdles or barriers to entry here; Murderbot is upfront about everything you could want and many things you don‚Äôt.

Murderbot perfectly embodies every anxious, cynical, socially awkward person. I love so much about Murderbot, and it was easy to relate to this genderless, self-aware, security android. The melodramatic, cynical, sarcastic inner monologue. The social anxiety and lack of social awareness. The voracious appetite for media. The conflicting desire and fear of being treated as more than a SecUnit. The contempt for human stupidity. It‚Äôs all gold. And while it‚Äôs a bit much in this first book, I have high hopes it‚Äôs leading somewhere interesting.

Wells plants a lot of seeds here. It‚Äôs hard to see in what direction the series will lead, which is awfully refreshing, and I may be new to her writing, but I have a lot of faith in her ability to nurture these seeds into something extraordinary in future instalments.

All Systems Red is the first book in Martha Wells' Murderbot Diaries series and it was a brilliant introduction. Set in a universe where space travel is a regular occurrence and scientific expeditions to far flung planets are sold to the lowest bidder its fairly common for things to go wrong but on their latest mission things are about to get very difficult for our narrator, the part organic / part robot Muderbot.

All intergalactic expeditions must take along a company supplied security unit, ostensibly to protect the humans but equally used to report back any interesting scientific findings. Murderbot is the SecUnit for a team of scientists, one of two groups currently working on a previously unexplored planet. Well aware of their previous failures Murderbot can't afford to make any mistakes on this latest mission, they just need to keep their head down, get the job done and then they'll be free to spend all their time watching the entertainment feed. After a series of strange equipment malfunctions they end up completely losing contact with the other group on planet, a sure sign that something isn't right. Murderbot has to do whatever it takes to keep the humans alive but that may be easier said than done considering they have no idea who the enemy is.

This was a really fun novella to read, Murderbot is such an interesting character with a snarky sense of humour and a definite dislike of having to interact with the people they're supposed to protect. All Systems Red may be a novella but Martha Wells packs a lot in, the combination of humour and action makes this a very quick and easy read and it definitely left me wanting to see more of Murderbot and the rest of the crew.

Martha Wells is one of my favorite authors, so I don't know why it took me so long to read this series. Possibly it's because I didn't immediately buy the hardcover edition; I may or may not have mentioned that my e-reader puts me to sleep, so I'm reluctant to use it for anything but going over my own manuscripts. I really don't know what I was thinking.

It's brilliant, of course. The voice of the narrator, Murderbot, is beautifully strong and conveys the character's personality perfectly. I was thinking about how relatively scanty the descriptions of this society are, but that makes sense because of that strong narrative voice. Everything we know is filtered through Murderbot's experience, and calling the series a diary drives home the fact that people don't spend a lot of time thinking or writing about stuff everyone knows. There's no section laying out the details of the company (I love that it's lower-case company) and yet I have a very clear idea of what it does and what it's like.

I already knew, because I have read all of Wells's novels, that she is excellent at conveying character, and the research team of humans comes across as vividly unique in a way a SecUnit would see them. We don't get to know all of them, but the few Murderbot interacts with more deeply are charming or irritating or na√Øve, enough that I worried for their safety.

And Murderbot. I was tempted, in the first maybe half of the novella, to ascribe its personality changes to "becoming human." But of course that's not what's going on. Murderbot has seen humans, both its clients and the ones on the many many shows it watches, and for all its growing desire to protect them, it has no desire to become one. It might be better to say that Murderbot is becoming a person, an individual with needs and desires, and I loved seeing it cope with those developing emotions. (I absolutely love every time it says it has to stop to have an emotion. I don't remember if it says that specifically in this book, but it comes up enough that it gets me every time.)

Dr. Mensah is a remarkable character whose interactions with Murderbot are something else I love. Though because of that, the ending caught me off-guard: 
Mensah buys Murderbot outright, intending to give it freedom in her world, and I was sort of excited by the possibility. So I missed that Mensah, in telling Murderbot she would be its guardian (not much different from owner), didn't say that this was only until Murderbot acclimated to freedom. So Murderbot fleeing was a surprise, and yet clearly the only solution.

When I finally came to my senses and bought all four books, I decided to read them back to back because, you know, why waste any more time? This turned out not to work, but I did read them over the course of two days. So I have more reviews to write. It also means I know they just keep getting better.

'All Systems Red' was such an amazing, fun book. I love Murderbot so much. There's such a relatable humour to it, and it's so loveable. I listened to this book as an audiobook, and although I usually prefer reading, it was great to listen to. It's the perfect novella in my eyes.

I'm going to keep this review relatively short because I wasn't able to make notes. Murderbot is a security robot hired to look after a team of scientists as they survey a planet. It's hacked its governor module and so is technically free to do as it likes, which mostly consists of watching a lot of TV. When the team realise that their planetary data is hijacked to hide information about dangerous wildlife they need to figure out who's responsible, and why.


All they had was Murderbot, who just wanted everyone to shut up and leave it alone so it could watch the entertainment feed all day.



The highlight of this book is Murderbot itself. It has such a fantastic narrative voice, and that's coming from someone who usually prefers third-person narratives. There's an amazing sense of humour to it that's both dry and relatable. Murderbot doesn't like talking to people. It's incredibly awkward. I love a socially anxious robot. At one point it's asked if it's okay and it gets up to stand in the corner of the room in embarrassment. I love it.


Yes, talk to Murderbot about its feelings. The idea was so painful I dropped to 97 percent efficiency.


I also love that Murderbot is a sentient and empathetic character without needing to be human. There's an awareness that it's a different type of individual, that it doesn't necessarily want what humans want. It seems like that's going to be explored in the next novel which I'm excited about.


It‚Äôs wrong to think of a construct as half bot, half human. It makes it sound like the halves are discrete, like the bot half should want to obey orders and do its job and the human half should want to protect itself and get the hell out of here. As opposed to the reality, which was that I was one whole confused entity, with no idea what I wanted to do.


Also! Although the background cast isn't hugely developed, likely because Murderbot doesn't care too much about human information, they are amazingly diverse. You've got a cast full of people of colour, a W/W relationship and causal mentions to polyamory. I always love a sci-fi setting where bigotry doesn't seem to be an important factor.


You may have noticed that when I do manage to care, I‚Äôm a pessimist.


I'm looking forward to the next in the series because it'd be great to see how Murderbot further develops, as well as get more information surrounding worldbuilding through its eyes.

I loved it!

Seriously, I haven't found any flaws or imperfections.
All Systems Red is gripping, exciting sci-fi novella about Murderbot, serving as SecBot to protect a research team on an uninhabited planet. Until things go very very wrong.

The story is told from 1st person pov of Murderbot, who refers to itself as it. It hacked its governor control, so it has a free will and it chooses to spend its free time reading books and watch tv serials. Has there ever been more relatable bot? Murderbot is cranky, pessimistic and it has the whole "leave-me-alone-you-weird-humans-I-want-to-watch-shows-in-peace" attitude. It doesn't have any gender or sex-related organs, it clarifies it in next for the reader. I love the feeling like it was telling me the story. Its pov was hilarious to read.
I love Murderbot, don't fight me on it.

The plot has mystery elements, action and suspense. The tech side of the setting was interesting. I can't wait to see more of the world and my beloved Murderbot in next installments.
I laughed so much on Murderbot's constant jabs at the company and what a cheap asshats they are, as big corporations always are.

I love the supporting cast of characters. It's a bunch of diverse individuals, many people of color, at least two of them are confirmed to be in polyamorous relationship. It's normalized in the world the story takes place in. The leader of the research team is Dr Mensah, woman of color; she's such a capable leader, she's smart and caring. I hope we'll get to see her in the next installments. The rest of the crew are Ratthi, Pin-Lee, Arada, Gurathin, Volescu and Bharadwaj. The dynamic between the team and Murderbot was so well developed, I love the dynamics!

When I read novellas, I often want them to be a full-length novels. While I don't mind a full novel about Murderbot (@ Martha Wells, pretty please!), All Systems Red works perfectly as a novella, I wouldn't change a thing about it. And that last sentence of the book ended me, no kidding.

I highly recommend to read it!
I can't wait to read the sequel!!!

UPDATE: I have now read this book twice and listened to the audiobook once as well, and after three goes through I can safely say that this is a fantastic book. I still agree with everything from my review - despite thinking slightly more of the story now, so I will not be changing or updating it and the review still reflects my thoughts and opinion after just one read.
_____________

I feel rather conflicted about All Systems Red. It had a lot of potential, and I certainly enjoyed it, but I felt it also missed the mark slightly in places.

Spoiler-free synopsis:
A research team has landed on a not-yet-inhabited planet to survey and collect data on soil composition and mineral deposits.
With the team is a SecUnit; a sentient, half biotic/half organic hybrid bodyguard. These units are standard issue and it is through the eyes of this SecUnit, who refers to itself as Murderbot, that the story is told.
When another survey teams communications drop out and portions of the digital maps they were given start to go missing, Murderbots's research team realises that something is very wrong and that there may be a conspiracy surrounding the planet and possibly corruption in the political systems that put them there.

It seemed to me that this could have been a decent short story, or a great novel of a longer length. As it was, it hung somewhere in the middle.
This is not necessarily a bad thing, but there were elements of the story that I thought we could have had less of, and other elements that I wish we had seen more of.
I guess I will find out if book 2, 'Artificial Condition', contains more of the latter. I hope so.

The combination of story and perspective was very interesting. So much of what was going on was filtered through the lense of our sentient SecUnit.
Her feelings, attitude, prejudices, technological abilities, background, origin and her past experiences all lead to a very cohesive and well realised view point, which is rare in my experience with books that try to do similar. This is an incredibly unique protagonist that despite who they are, will be very relatable to many.

I wish the human characters had been given a bit more page time, or at least had been made more separable to each other.
I found myself regularly getting confused between who is who and which ones played which role in the team.
Although, thinking about it now, I suppose that this helped us gain more of a footing as an outsider. Hiding behind the opaque face mask, full body armour, pretending not to care about anything but the job at hand.

As for how the story developed I thought the pacing was a bit staggered or clunky. There was a lot of talking and making plans - which is fine, but then suddenly the action and consequences had seemingly happened within another page or two! And due to the nature of said actions (keeping it spoiler-free) we rarely saw the aftermath either.
It made sense, but it could be a bit jarring and I couldn't help but wish we had seen a bit more of that stuff.

As for the last few chapters and the conclusion of the story, I REALLY enjoyed it.
It was wrapped up really well, and it left me wanting to start the next book straight away, despite my somewhat mixed feelings on the book as a whole.

I can completely see why this book/series is so popular, but I could also understand if this book wasn't for you.
If you have read and enjoyed either the Imperial Radch series by Ann Leckie,'Excession' by Iain M. Banks or 'Dogs of War' by Adrian Tchaikovsky then I think this book would be for you. Likewise if you enjoy(ed) All Systems Red then I would recommend checking these others out as well.

3.5 stars, rounded up for potential.

________________

Thank you for reading my review!

As I said before, I will definitely be reading the other books in the series at some point. So keep your eyes peeled for those coming in the near future.

Up next for though, for sci-fi, it's going to be Surface Detail by Iain M. Banks.
And as for fantasy it's going to be Elantris by Brandon Sanderson.
Two books that I've been looking forward to a lot, by two of my favourite authors!

Thanks again. Stay safe and keeping reading!

Murderbot is a security unit that hacks its own governor module, gaining the freedom to do whatever it wants without following the orders of its clients. And what does it choose to do with its newfound autonomy? Spend thousands of hours watching movies and TV shows.
