The best straight SF I've read so far in 2017: All Systems Red is a longish novella/shortish book with an engagingly snarky protagonist, humor, mystery, excitement, interesting characters and enough plot twists that I devoured it even more than I normally devour books. Once again Martha Wells has created a completely believable non-human protagonist and I loved it (shout out also to the terrific samurai-esque cover art created by Jaime Jones - cover illustrators don't always get the kudos they deserve from readers.)

Red really delivers in the main character of Murderbot (the book is first person from Murderbot's POV.) Murderbot is physically an organic-techological synthesis and the narration subtly reflects that synthesis; the character growth is beautifully done. And yes, I like typing 'Murderbot.'

I also think 'Murderbot' would be a hellagood name for a cat.

This is the second book I've read fairly recently that follows an AI character, the other being Becky Chambers' A Closed and Common Orbit. There's more meat to Chambers' (longer) book but I enjoyed Wells' Murderbot more as a completely other-than-human intelligence (Chambers' AI character is more about an AI becoming human).

In All Systems Red Murderbot is growing its experience as its unique self and adding to that personality rather than learning how to be human, a fascinating perspective. Murderbot feels like a realistic non-human entity.

Although I got my copy from the library, my love for Wells' writing is compelling me to pop for the hard copy and I'm already slavering for Murderbot Diaries #2.

I really enjoyed this novella which introduced the fantastic Murderbot character. The premise is that in the future (200 years? I don't think it is ever fully specified), corporations rule the galaxy (or an arm of it, also not clearly stated) and as they pillage and terraform various planets, moons, and asteroids, they employ SecUnits (potent, lethal military android used for, well, murder by corporate unities in the story) rather than private security to protect their interests. This is particularly the case in a zone called the Corporate Rim. Our protagonist has removed the governor which basically gives it free will and we are inside its head listening as it "wakes up". It learns about human behavior by watching soap operas obsessively, sometimes providing an excellent comic background.
Our hero makes friends with Dr Mensah from an ecological mission, and this character plays an important role in subsequent stories as one of Murderbot's best friends.
What makes the story so entertaining is that (1) Murderbot has a hilarious and deprecating sense of humor, (2) the story has a great murder mystery at the center of it, and (3) the powers of Murderbot to multi-process, hook into nearly any tech around it, and get healed after catastrophic injuries all makes for fun reading.
So, for light and highly entertaining soft science fiction, All Systems Red is a great novella.

Our hero makes friends with Dr Mensah from an ecological mission, and this character plays an important role in subsequent stories as one of Murderbot's best friends.
What makes the story so entertaining is that (1) Murderbot has a hilarious and deprecating sense of humor, (2) the story has a great murder mystery at the center of it, and (3) the powers of Murderbot to multi-process, hook into nearly any tech around it, and get healed after catastrophic injuries all makes for fun reading.
So, for light and highly entertaining soft science fiction, All Systems Red is a great novella.

Rating 4 out of 5 | B+ Sardonic, Robots with a personality.

Synopsis

In a distant world, a group of planetary explorers are engaged in the survey of the land which has been recently uncovered. This group of novice surveyors/ scientists from a group known as PreservationAux had bought a commission from the corporation to scope out the planet‚Äôs resources. Once the survey was completed, if the effort was worth the profit they would get a larger share.

Assisting and guarding them in this mission is the security unit, which refers to itself as the Murderbot. Part and parcel of the contract from the company, along with the habitats, hub systems, hoppers, and everything necessary to sustain life on the unknown planet.

The SecUnit which calls itself Murderbot, was involved in a previous accident, where faulty implants from the company had malfunctioned; resulting in it slaughtering every person in the vicinity. While a terrible legal & PR nightmare, the Secunit was far too valuable to be scrapped, and so the company rebooted it, loaded new programs, as well as new governor modules the main function of which was to make sure that the Murderbot was never capable of inflicting harm on the humans that were its charges.

Unknown to the company, the survey group or anyone for that matter, this particular SecUnit had managed to hack into its governor module, giving it a level of independence. More importantly, no longer leaving it tethered with the failsafe protocols to protect the humans. What does our murderbot do with this new found freedom? Does it go about a second round of manslaughter? Or does it run away into the wide cosmos to unfettered freedom?

Neither, it downloads several terabytes worth of entertainment programs, binge watching it during its idle time, in speeds incomprehensive to mere human minds. For the most part it is content to perform its assigned job, protect the humans, watch its serials and make sure to act like an obedient automaton so as not to draw unneeded attention to its unique condition.

Which is proving to be more difficult than it thought, as the humans which are under its protection are being subject to dangerous situations on a constant basis. Now Murderbot has to make a decision; does it continue to feign ignorance, leaving the humans to their fate; Or help them live, thereby exposing his condition to scrutiny and possible termination?


Thoughts

Murderbot has quite a personality; even when it might not come across as likable/ comprehensive to others, it sticks to its own nature and makes decisions based on a complex mix of indifference and neutral altruism.

Murderbot, contrary to what it calls itself, doesn‚Äôt hold any animosity to humans. If you want to categorize its feelings, it would be something like being ‚ÄòLawful Neutral‚Äô. It takes care of the humans because they are its responsibility. But, technically, since it has hacked the Governor module, it has no compulsion to carry out said duty. It does regardless, because it has a sense of responsibility.

Murderbot is pretty indifferent to humans, and doesn‚Äôt want to get close to them, or interact with them to any degree. This group from PreservationAux, largely leave him to his own devices, and unlike other humans don‚Äôt exploit him, or treat him like a slave. They give him space, and a modicum of respect. This makes them appreciable to the murderbot. And while it doesn‚Äôt care what happens to them, because it likes how they treat it, Murderbot does everything in their power to make sure they stay alive.

It is even possessive when it comes to the survey group. When it learns of Rogue altered SpecUnits and a rival group of humans who were antagonistic to their own, it is indignant that the EvilCorp as it calls them, would dare to hurt ‚Äòhis humans‚Äô. Even when it says it doesn‚Äôt care for the humans, Murderbot has shown capability for more complex if not contrary emotions. This is also made evident on multiple occasions, when it jeopardizes its own safety, to ensure the survival of the humans.

Murderbot rarely behaves in a manner that you would expect someone in its position to behave. Even during the climax, when the crisis has been averted, and the humans are delivered to safety, it makes decisions which are right for it, not that the humans feel are right for it.

It has been a while since I‚Äôve enjoyed a Synthetic character this much, since Marvin & his clinical depression from ‚ÄòThe Hitchhiker‚Äôs guide to the Galaxy‚Äô. Not that I‚Äôm saying Murderbot is better than Marvin, that is a position which shall remain uncontested. But the range of emotions which Murderbot exhibits, and the spark of individuality which fuels much of its decisions are a breath of fresh air.




The story is simple, and focused on a series of events of limited scope, in some unexplored hunk of dirt out in the universe. With the exception of Murderbot, we don‚Äôt get into more than surface level interactions with the other humans in the Preservation Aux Survey team. The one who is most developed is Dr. Mensah, and that too due to her close interactions with Murderbot.

She is its most favorite human, and we can't help but be slightly influenced by that notion as well. A natural leader, she has great empathy, and is willing to treat Murderbot with respect, and as an equal, even before she learned of its condition.

But perhaps when that wish for altruism crossed over to her trying to dictate Murderbot‚Äôs life & future, that is when it cuts off all ties and vanishes to the wind. It is perhaps because, regardless of her good intention, Mensah and the others failed to understand that Murderbot didn‚Äôt want to be helped, or want to be treated like a human. Just to be left to its own devices.

The rising actions and setup of the story is surface level, and ends far too abruptly. Perhaps because, from the start, the focus was meant to be on the personality & inner thoughts of Murderbot, our protagonist.

For a short story, and a surprisingly quick read, All Systems red, manages to explore the psyche of our unique and interesting character, without being too heavy handed or exposition heavy. That is a great accomplishment for the writer, and I look forward to reading the other entries in the series.

Original Review 6/24/18:

Yes, talk to Murderbot about it's feelings. The idea was so painful I dropped to 97 percent efficiency.

I'm not much of a sci-fi gal, since the jargon and overall concepts usually confuse me. I also am just not really into futuristic stories or stories set in space, since I can't conceptualize a lot of whats going on. But after having some success with the Illuminae Files series, I'm intrigued by the genre. I picked up All Systems Red because it's less than 150 pages and I've seen some pretty good reviews of it, so I figured if I should start with sci-fi anywhere, it should be here.

Overall, I liked this book. Murderbot is hilarious and honestly one of the most relatable characters I've come across. The trope of a self-aware AI with a sense of humor is always so funny and appealing to me, and I loved reading from its point-of-view. I think it's pretty awesome when an author can make a robot relatable.

I, for some reason, got a very femme vibe from Murderbot, even though it has no gender. I've never gotten a female impression from any AI I've ever read, but there's something about this antisocial queen that tugged on my heartstrings. Maybe I just saw a bit too much of myself in Murderbot. I think one of the funniest parts of the book is when Dr. Mensah asked if Murderbot would like to spend time with the crew, and Murderbot--who cannot control its facial expressions readily--gives a look of absolute horror at the prospect of spending time with people. Like, bitch, me too. Talking to people is hard. Murderbot also stands in the corner of the room facing the wall when talking in group settings and I just wish that behavior was acceptable for me, because same.

The writing is a little choppy and not very pretty, but I've never read anything else by Martha Wells, so I'm not sure if this was a tactic to make it truly seem like a robot was telling us the story or if she's just a writer who doesn't care about whether her words sound nice. I didn't hate it, but sometimes the choppy wording and sentences could be a tad awkward and I would have to reread them. But the writing lent itself to letting the story move fast, which I always like.

What flopped in this book for me was the plot and the ending. The last two chapters were confusing and vague, and I couldn't tell you what the GrayCris group was trying to accomplish and why Murderbot's group had anything to do with it. It was never explained, and I found the fact that Murderbot was unconcious for a majority of the action scenes to be a tad lazy on the author's part. The last chapter was also weird, I don't understand quite what happened since it seemed like everything important had been completely missed by Murderbot and no one bothered to explain it to them. The last few pages seemed out of character for Murderbot as well, and I have no idea why it ended that way or where it will take us in the future.

I know this is a series with 3 more books, so I'm guessing we'll learn a lot more about that planet they were on, their mission, the GrayCris group, and why everything happened the way it did. But it seems kind of silly to me to have a 150 page book were things sort of happened and but never got explained. I wanted to love this story, because I really love Murderbot, but nothing seemed to make much sense by the end.

I will definitely continue the series since these books are so short and I want more of Murderbot's hilarious narration. I just hope that this story doesn't go in a completely random direction like the ending seemed to promise. I need answers, and I also need more of the human characters introduced in order to truly care for this story. If the next book is solely about Murderbot's journey and we never see those people again or get any answers I'll be pretty pissed. 150 pages just wasn't enough time to articulate an effective plot, at least for this author.

This was my first experience with Martha Wells and her science fiction Murderbot series. It has an interesting premise, to say the least. The story is told from the point of view from a robot, referred to as security unit. Tis unit has managed to override its governor installed device that directs and controls its actions, which has enabled it to develop a sense of independence and free agency. It has named itself Murderbot, hates being around humans, but yet has a voracious appetite for watching serial television shows.

In this first novella in the series, ‚ÄúAll Systems Red,‚Äù Murderbot is part of a corporate (called ‚ÄúThe Company) financed scientific expedition on an alien planet. His role is protecting the research scientists because safety isn‚Äôt always as good as it could be in uncharted space. Unfortunately. Murderbot discovers information about the local fauna is missing from their survey information, as well as sections missing from their local area mappings. Then things get worse when they lose contact with the other expedition group on the other side of the planet. It‚Äôs up to Murderbot and his team of scientists to figure out what is happening before it‚Äôs too late.

There was a lot of buzz for this series, both in favor and against it for various reasons. After finishing the first novella, I can see support for both sides.

Things I liked:

It is a unique approach that is delivered for the most part in an interesting and refreshing style. I thought about how hard it must be to write in first-person and pull off such a challenging view.
Wells succeeds fairly well with this conceptual approach.

The mystery plotting and characters were both stronger than average. Although the world building was limited by the novella structure, it was good enough to want me to read the next one in the series.

Things I didn‚Äôt really like:

Because it won a lot of awards, including the Hugo, Nebula, and Locus, to name a few ‚Äì I was expecting a pretty high level of quality. Although I liked it, I didn‚Äôt find myself loving it or being as enamored with it as I was hoping for. I know that sounds a bit subjective, and it is. I am sure that there will be many who disagree with my assessment, but it‚Äôs my view and I am sticking with it.

My other critique is one that many have already hit upon, and it is a passionate criticism from many when I looked at various Goodreads and Amazon reviews. It‚Äôs nothing new, but I am rather surprised by the pricing for these Murderbot novellas. Hardcover/softcover copies run about $12 or $13 while Kindle/electronic versions run around $11. They are novellas, not midsize or lengthy novels ‚Äì around 150 pages in length ‚Äì which makes the pricing seem cost prohibitive. Since this is already a sore point for many people, I will refrain from further comments.

Overall, this was an interesting read that provided hope for further development and potential in future books. Definitely worth reading. However, on a personal level, I am not sure it lives up fully to the accolades it has received. Wells brings a unique voice told through a dark and distinctive android character. One that is her own and she delivers it in a style that is both clinical and exploratory of human emotions and desires. Overall, I liked it enough to give the second novella a read. However, I will be checking it out from my local library, rather than paying the current price. That‚Äôs where I am at for now. We‚Äôll see how it progresses before I commit to anything more‚Ä¶

Martha Wells‚Äô ‚ÄòThe Murderbot Diaries‚Äô can be compared with Nnedi Okorafor‚Äôs ‚ÄòBinti‚Äô in narrative style: first person accord through a marginalized character, in a serialized story, structured through novellas. I didn‚Äôt go well with ‚ÄòBinti‚Äô, but, ‚ÄòAll Systems Red‚Äô hit all the right spots. It was refreshingly short, minimal in execution, well fleshed and lively, despite its premise where, literally, all systems were red.

Protagonist is a security bot -half android and half human, like a cyborg, and from the story it can be inferred that this futuristic society has co-existence of humans, bots and special purpose half bots. Interestingly and also a bit disturbingly, the murderbot is never assigned a gender or a name, and is almost treated as a property by the expedition team than an individual, thanks to the universal SecUnit armour that covers everything organic and metallic. Author doesn‚Äôt treat this as an existential problem, as the Murderbot itself is content with strict work interactions.

As I progressed further in the story, I started to identify myself with the Meursault like SecUnit than its human companions. Its shy, prefers face and expressions hidden under visor, and escapes loneliness by watching television series. Murderbots have a governing module as per job purpose, and their decision making is strictly through game theory probabilities, but the organic parts make it constantly self-aware during the process. Even now I am feeling a little discomfort in addressing Murderbot as Murderbot or it. Turns out Shakespeare was wrong; there is a lot in a name.

Though boasted as Westworld and Culture in bio, I was more or less reminded of Halo and Master Chief during the read. Anyway, this book is a prime example of how fun and uplifting reading could be, and I am more than eager to enter the next installment.

Okay, first, "Murderbot" is definitely a misleading sobriquet. The protagonist may apply that nickname to itself, but ironically. I mention this because the title was kind of a turn-off for me, but this whole "murderous android" thing is very much overblown.

The protagonist is a construct with both organic parts and tech parts. Definitely a person, it is legally equipment. Generally it's rented to clients it doesn't think highly of, by a company it thinks even less of, which as you might imagine has cased it to develop a certain bitter cynicism. Despite this, it can't help noticing that its current clients are actually pretty nice people. When someone starts trying to kill them all, it gets personally involved ... and so the story unrolls, with a fast pace that keeps you involved straight through to the satisfying conclusion. I already know I will enjoy re-reading the first novella before reading the second.

If you like:

I've been thinking of Breq from Leckie's Ancillary series recently, and I must say that Murderbot reminds me of Breq in some important ways. Definitely not human, definitely a person -- and actually similar as well in how out of touch it is with its own feelings. This is another take on a nonhuman protagonist who is a good person without ever thinking of itself that way. I think people who appreciated the Ancillary series ought to like this novella quite a bit.

All Systems Red, the first installment in Martha Wells' The Murderbot Diaries and winner of the 2018 Hugo, Locus, and Nebula Awards, is a heck of a lot of fun. This is a novella, so the premise is pretty simple - a rogue android has to help keep the humans who have contracted it for security alive during a planetary survey mission. Naturally, Wells inserts a few wrinkles along the way that point to something larger and more nefarious. A murderbot has to earn its pay, after all.

What separates All Systems Red from the pack of droid hero science fiction is the character of Murderbot itself. Murderbot has hacked the governor module that controls and dictates its behavior, making it a free agent, if not for the fact that it has to hide this tidbit of information from its human employers. Despite being fully self-aware and keenly intelligent, Murderbot is still listed as inventory in the Company that contracts it out for security services, so certain ruses must be maintained if Murderbot doesn't want to see itself reformatted and re-enslaved to its corporate masters.

Murderbot may not be human, although it does have some fleshy components, but it is most decidedly a person. Wells gives enough depth to Murderbot to make it sympathetic, relying on the android's personality and issues of human bias and notions of superiority in our historical dealings with artificial intelligences to give us a healthy degree of perspective on where exactly Murderbot is coming from.

And where Murderbot is coming from is decidedly simple - it hates humans and just wants to be left alone to watch its favorite downloaded television shows. Never before have I found an artificial intelligence to be so utterly relatable! While I can fully sympathize with Murderbot's ambitions, it's pretty damn hilarious listening to its encounters with its new human crew and their attempts to humanize a wryly grumpy killing machine, and how Murderbot responds to such showings of support and empathy. The scientific team it is charged with protecting is nicely drama free, but Wells manages to wring a good bit of emotive action out of how Murderbot and its crew respond to each other. Wells doesn't get deeply philosophical about the nature of life, intelligence, and free will, but she does raise a few poignant issues worth thinking about over the course of this short book.

Experiencing All Systems Red in audiobook format, though, leaves me slightly conflicted. It took me a while to warm to Kevin R. Free's narration, and while his reading here is serviceable I wish it were more engaging. Murderbot actually has feelings - it gets angry, its gets sarcastic, and it knows when it needs to be emotionally manipulative to draw out desired responses from the humans around it. Free's reading is dry and largely monotone; this makes for a dull listen despite Murderbot being anything but a dull character. I wish Free would have taken a livelier approach to the material, but I did eventually come around to his style - not enough to rave about his vocal showmanship, but enough that I'm still interested in pursuing this series in audio rather than switching over to print (at least for book two).

Although the narration didn't do the story justice, the character of Murderbot is most definitely one worth paying attention to and has me eager to sink straight into Artificial Condition next. I can't wait to see what further hijinks my new favorite anti-social killing machine gets up to!

A Snickers candy-bar has three things going for it: it‚Äôs sweet, it‚Äôs crunchy, and it‚Äôs only 1.86 oz. Cause you know that saying, too much of a good thing is a bad thing? With Snickers, it‚Äôs more like too much of a bad thing is, uh, still a bad thing‚Ä¶ but in small quantities, eh, not so bad, takes the edge off at least.

That more or less summarizes how I feel about these murder-bot diaries: the protagonist (self-named ‚ÄúMurderbot‚Äù) is a bit crunchy and a bit sweet, and it‚Äôs good that these are novellas and not full length novels. Just like a Snickers bar, they‚Äôre real easy to consume, and I don‚Äôt want to undervalue that. Reading each in one sitting is a great way to spend the afternoon.

And to give more substantive praise, probably the best part of these novellas is the way they extend corporate dystopia into the realm of space exploration. The Murderbot begins its life as a ‚ÄúSecBot,‚Äù a security/protection android that its company REQUIRES for exploration/survey groups to qualify for insurance (and also lets the company steal data‚Ä¶). While corporate dystopia is nothing new to sci-fi, this more intimate boots-on-the-ground perspective feels fresh within the context of space exploration.

However, these are otherwise absolute junk food. These are books heavily featuring robots and AI and hacking, written by someone who KNOWS ABSOLUTELY NOTHING ABOUT ANY OF THAT. You know that amazingly absurd 1995 film, Hackers? That‚Äôs about the level of accuracy of hacking/robotics/AI in this book.

In writing, we have this phrase ‚Äúwrite what you know.‚Äù I hate that phrase. I despise it utterly. Please, writers, don‚Äôt restrict yourself to ‚Äúwhat you know.‚Äù Please use your empathy to write from perspectives not your own. Please depict worlds beyond what we currently know.

But do your research. I‚Äôm not asking for a textbook on encryption or cyber-sec. But if you‚Äôve written a quarter of a million words in which ‚Äúhacking‚Äù is the primary method by which your protagonist resolves conflicts and you never use basic terminology like ‚Äúfirewall‚Äù or ‚Äúencryption‚Äù (much less sophisticated jargon like ‚Äúsanitizing input‚Äù or ‚Äúair-gap‚Äù) then your story is probably bullshit, isn‚Äôt it?

In that respect, I find it a bit disturbing that people nominated and then awarded these books for not just one Hugo but FOUR. MORE ACTUALLY! They wanted to give MORE! AND two Nebulas. That's like giving the story equivalent of a MCDONALD‚ÄôS the ‚Äúbest restaurant award.‚Äù For better or worse, the field of science fiction literature is now dominated by people who have only the most tenuous grasp of actual science, technology, mathematics, and philosophy.

Also, as a final and related note, each of these books is like $20. I‚Äôm sorry but what? You‚Äôre charging steak-dinner prices for a candy bar. Ironic, considering this is a book set against a backdrop of corporate greed.

What an entertaining read. A robot trained to kill hostile fauna on alien planets while working alongside human exploration teams is the narrator. And what a character this robot, which calls itself a Murderbot, is.

Murderbot hacks the governor module present in its system, essentially allowing it to decide whether to obey the commands sent by the clients who hired it, the choice which it would not have if the module had been operational.

The premise is utterly intriguing. And the first few lines of the book promise a great story and an entertaining tone for it. And the author delivers those promises.


I COULD HAVE BECOME a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don‚Äôt know, a little under 35,000 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.


So this Murderbot uses all spare time it can get to watch sitcoms and entertainment content, despising human interaction and its job.

I had thoroughly enjoyed reading this, not just because of the POV of the story or the tone of it, but also because of the story it had to offer. I was skeptical about the plot because how good would a plot be where the main character is a funny and brooding killing robot, but I was pleasantly surprised by how intense the story was. The action scenes and the suspense was so good, brief moments though they were. The plot gets a tad too contrived in the end for my liking, but this is a complaint I seem to be making for almost every book I read these days, so it wasn't that big a deal truly.

I think people who are looking for something refreshing in terms of POV and story should read this, it's short and awesome.

The story is set in a futuristic world of planetary travel and exploration, and told from the point of view of a construct of organic and inorganic parts that names itself "Murderbot" (a morbid attempt at humor after a failed mission). Hacking its governor, the processing unit that controls its behavior, Murderbot conceals its independence from its human clients and spends its downtime watching entertainment vids of space operas.

The exceptional element of this story is the voice of Murderbot, described by some as cynical and sulky. I found Murderbot charming as it tries to navigate its first encounter with humans who realize that it is independent of controls. There's a larger question, of course, of the sentience of the other constructs in the Murderbot universe, and the answer is not provided in this book. As a fan of Asimov, however, I am definitely interested in seeing where this thread of thought might lead.

A very clean, well-told story with an immensely likeable protagonist. I think I've read too much sci-fi as it felt very familiar: both the character and the expedition.

But honestly, a solid little book. Looking forward to the next one.

Update:
1.5 years later I'm rereading this for bookclub and enjoyed it all over again. I sat down planning to just read the first 50 pages and blew right through it: Wells feeds an easy narrative. With hindsight, this first story is simple and has some intrigue. It could easily have faded into nothing and then we wouldn't have had all of the cool follow-up adventures that Murderbot goes on, so I'm glad it got famous.
Initially I gave this a 4-star but on the reread I'm dropping it to a 3.5.

Most of my enjoyment comes from empathizing with MB's social anxiety. Wells manages perfectly to capture the panic and desire for retreat in awkward social situations. Everything else: the politics, the tech, the science isn't fully developed in this volume.

If you haven't read the series and this is your first book: keep going. The narrator becomes much more developed and there are nice surprises in store.

Murderbot Diaries: 4/5

‚ÄúIn the creche, our moms always said that fear was an artificial condition. It's imposed from the outside‚Ä¶You should do the things you're afraid of‚Äù.

Murderbot is one of those stories that holds a special place in the hearts of those who read it. I'd wager that those that don't normally pick up Sci-Fi would find a nook to keep their experience with Murderbot. The Sci-Fi here is just a catalyst that allows for the real story to shine. A study on human existence and emotions through the lens of an anthropomorphic artificial construct, that all of a sudden has free will. The existential dread that Murderbot encounters and the way it chooses to cope with the situations is like many of us; Escapism through art, i.e. movies, shows, reading.

Me being me and catching up on all the books i've missed, I was able to binge these four back-to-back. It lent itself to being able to be immersed in the story. The writing was so structurally sound it's a no brainer why Martha Wells has been nominated for and won so many awards. A master of the craft if you will. And even though Murderbot is at its core about a melancholy robot struggling with deep human emotions, Wells weaves in comedy and does it well. It's inherently wholesome.

Wells is able to propel the story forward without it feeling rushed, forced, or predictable. When an author is able to deliver on that it makes the reading experience flow smoothly. Everything that Murderbot accomplishes feels earned. His wins feel like our wins. His emotional growth feels like our growth. I also just have to smirk about the fact that as Murderbot grows more mature, so does his choice of words. LOL. It's just hilarious to have Murderbot just nonchalantly throw out an F bomb. Love it.

Murderbot is a great way to explore heavy themes in a cheeky package. And it has become a nice comfy read for me.

‚ÄúI was having an emotion, and I hate that‚Äù.


All Systems Red: 3.5/5

All Systems Red was a solid introduction to our new friend, Murderbot. We understand the basic groundwork for his goals and his reasons for his actions. This novella was a nice window into the universe we‚Äôre in, I just wanted a little more from it. It felt like this first entry could have been shorter and set the same hooks into readers.

Artificial Condition: 4/5

Artificial Condition gave us a broader scope of the universe and a deeper dive into Murderbot, which I enjoyed. We get to see Murderbot interact at length with another AI, also known as ART. This is a part of the story that was the cherry on top. In the environment between Murderbot and ART, Murderbot is playing the role of human and it makes for awesome scenes (Older sibling like). We get to experience Murderbot's first ‚Äúfriend‚Äù. Artificial Condition is also where we get to dive deeper into Murderbot‚Äôs history and learn a little about why he is the way he is. As Murderbot gets to spend more time independently and not as a robot-for-hire we get to see his personality at the forefront of the narrative.

Rogue Protocol:4.5/5

Rogue Protocol steps it up with everything that made the last two entries great. Not only does the action get turned up to 11 but so do the existential situations Murderbot gets put into. He meets Abene and her ‚Äúpet‚Äù robot Miki. He has to dissect the relationship between the two and desperately tries to understand the bond the two have. Can Murderbot call a human a friend? Is he more human than he realizes? Murderbot vs some combat robots? HELL YEAH!

Exit Strategy: 4/5

In Exit Strategy, Murderbot's emotional growth throughout the first three stories coalesces here when he finally faces what he's been pondering alone. Can he have human friends? Is Murderbot‚Äôs most recent actions the result of him wanting to help his new friends? He even posits this with him questioning if he is still hardwired to help humans or is this now his own choice. Does he care enough about Mensa to freely make the decision to help her? Now with the ability to be alone without his existence being in trouble, Murderbot can really dive deep into free will and come up with his own answer‚Ä¶ or maybe just watch some serials like we all probably do *Haha*

‚ÄúYoung humans can be impulsive. The trick is keeping them around long enough to become old humans‚Äù.

The Good
‚Äì Sharp storytelling
‚Äì Fun and entertaining
‚Äì Incredibly likeable main character
‚Äì Quick and easy to read

The Bad
‚Äì A few critically weak points in prose
‚Äì Hard to keep track of secondary characters at times

Legit, Murderbot charmed its way into my heart by the end of the first paragraph.

Story
Quick, straightforward and enjoyable.

After Murderbot‚Äîa security construct who's hacked itself into autonomy‚Äîrescues a member of the survey team under its protection from a dangerous creature not registered on the planet's flora and fauna list, the group realizes something is wrong. They're unsure if the missing details in their information are an attempt at sabotage or a genuine error on the company's part, who are known for cutting corners and supplying cheap equipment.

However, the necessary actions it takes to save Dr. Volescu and Dr. Bharadwaj reveal it's more human than the team believed: for one, the security bots have a human face. A "generic" one, but something human-looking all the same. If Murderbot's autonomy is discovered by the company, they will terminate it and scrap it for parts.

Murderbot does not want to be terminated and scrapped for parts. Murderbot wants to watch media programs.

Wells has combined a lovely mixture of fun, conversational storytelling with some brutal moments and questions about humanness. All Systems Red is entertaining and compulsively readable without feeling overwhelming. There were a couple parts that I thought could be tightened further or where Wells could dig in a little more. But overall it's a very, very good novella. There's almost always something to look forward to if there isn't anything already something interesting and enjoyable on the page.

Characters
Murderbot is a star. Murderbot makes All Systems Red a star.

Murderbot is both someone other and unfamiliar‚Äîhow it functions, what it's capable of, its position in the universe‚Äîand something painfully human and relatable. It's lazy. It's socially awkward. It really, really wants to watch some TV. In this way, Murderbot is both distinctly human and distinctly not, and it is a charming and wonderful narrator.

Something I loved about Murderbot from a world-building angle is how Wells balanced Murderbot's murder abilities with its comparative fragility. Is Murderbot terrifying compared to squishy humans? Absolutely. Can Murderbot take a frankly horrifying amount of damage while still remaining functional? Oh, yeah. But at the end of the day, it's still one security android comprised of cheap parts up against other security android comprised of cheap parts. To quote: This is how we fight: throw ourselves at each other and see whose parts give out first.

Murderbot is in charge of the safety of eight humans, who are somewhat frustrating to keep track of mentally. This is due in part to the restraints of the novella, and in part to what the story is trying to achieve. We need to care about these humans at least a little bit, but it doesn't make sense to flesh them out too deeply when there isn't room for in the narrative. Wells has come up with a delightful explanation for this in the book, but it doesn't change the fact that outside of Dr. Mensah and Dr. Gurathin, the cast is rather interchangeable.

Writing Style
Told in first person, something tense, Wells conveys All Systems Red in a conversational, accessible and wry style.

Despite this, there are some occasional weak points an established author should've eliminated from their prose by now‚Äînamely a surprising number of had hads.

Themes and Representation
Touches on the ethics and morality of ownership of self-aware beings.

There are minimal details about them, but the supporting cast was culturally diverse and there was at least one LGBT+ relationship among them. Polyamorous relationships and marriages are common.

Recommended For...
Those who want a short, well-rounded story with an immensely delightful main character.

[Relisten completed 7/2/2020 - This is one of the small collection of audiobooks in my Audible library that I listen to repeatedly. If I still had an Audible membership, I'd probably consider spending credits on the other works in the series. I do have paper copies now, though, so I'm just waiting for my current reading game to give me an opportunity to read Artificial Condition.]

Murderbot is a SecUnit that hacked its own governor module a while back. Instead of using its newfound freedom to go on a killing spree, it's been quietly putting a bare minimum amount of effort into its job in order to hide the massive amount of time and effort it's putting into surreptitiously consuming movies, serials, books, plays, and music. Its favorite serial is Rise and Fall of Sanctuary Moon.

Murderbot's current job, acting as security for a small group of scientists, is fairly easy, up until a large carnivorous creature that wasn't mentioned anywhere in the region's hazard report tries to eat one of the scientists. The gaps in the data could be the result of corporate cost-cutting, but Murderbot soon suspects sabotage.

Murderbot didn't really care about a lot of what was going on around it until circumstances forced it to care, which meant that certain aspects of the story didn't get as much attention as others. I'm still not entirely sure about a lot of the political details, and my knowledge of the human characters was mostly limited to a name and a general sense of their personalities.

That's okay, though, because I read this primarily for Murderbot, and I loved Murderbot. It preferred to spend as little time with humans as possible and absolutely hated having to talk about itself, being asked about its feelings, or standing out in anyway. Some of this stemmed from a desire to avoid having its hacked governor module discovered, but I also felt that Murderbot came across as being extremely introverted.

As the story progressed, Murderbot realized that it kind of liked most of the humans it was charged with protecting, which wasn't always a comfortable position for it to be in. Only one of its humans even vaguely got the hang of interacting with it in a way that put it at ease (as little eye contact as possible, and preferably via text rather than talking). Also, Murderbot was way more used to getting attached to fictional characters than real humans. A quote I liked and could relate to: "I hate having emotions about reality; I‚Äôd much rather have them about Sanctuary Moon." (62.9%)

If you go into this hoping for a lot of murdering, you'll probably be disappointed. There's a bit of action, but Murderbot isn't really a combat bot, it's a security bot with the cheapest possible software. Its fighting style isn't so much about brilliant skills and strategies as it is about throwing itself at an enemy until the enemy is dead, which is only possible because 1) Murderbot is hard to kill and 2) it has self-repairing abilities as long as it has access to its cubicle. I got a bit of a kick out of the difference between its reaction to its own injuries and the scientists' reactions. The scientists were worried because Murderbot's injuries would have killed a human, whereas Murderbot just wanted to avoid drawing attention to itself by having organic bits leak or fall off in public.

I loved so much about Murderbot: its sense of humor, its desire to avoid having to spend too much time around its humans, its thoughts about corporate cheapness, and its devotion to Sanctuary Moon (hundreds of episodes long and counting). The one thing I hated was that the story was over so quickly. I haven't bought the next work in the series yet, but I'm definitely going to.

(Original review posted on A Library Girl's Familiar Diversions.)

Murderbot is probably one of the most relatable characters for many because he personifies introverts. He just wants to be left alone, is awkward around people, does not know what to say or how to act, often makes people uncomfortable ‚Ä¶ is this all hitting a little too close to home? Sure, there are other examples out there, but they are mainly the side characters. I cannot, as I stand here today, think of another series where the MC is an awkward introvert. There are shy or quiet MCs. There are MCs who are awkward because they try too hard or the author thinks that they are being funny when they are not. But imagine talking to someone in a spaceship and when you start to talk to them they put their helmet on, make the face plate non-transparent, and then turn away from you before they talk. And best of all, the ‚Äòperson‚Äô is a biologic/synthetic mix!

I really liked the concept here but believe that some of the praise is probably overkill. The plot involves a survey on a hostile world gone wrong, but there was very little discussion about the ‚Äúworld‚Äù (both where they are and the broader galaxy in which the story occurs) or any of the other characters beyond Murderbot saying he either did it did not like a character (mostly centered on whether they liked him or not).

For a book where the secondary characters were (deliberately?) really underdeveloped, I loved it a lot.
It's about a SecUnit (a self-aware security droid) that calls itself "Murderbot" and has gone rogue - it has hacked its governor module to access the combined feed of entertainment channels (it's a bored rogue bot). Now it can act freely, but that doesn't mean it will leave the humans in danger.

I loved reading in the Murderbot's PoV. I was afraid it would sound mechanical, but it didn't - and it was really entertaining. A shy, murderous droid. It works.

I loved how this book avoided the "AI falls in love and discovers they're more human than they thought" trope - one of the many overused subtropes of "romantic love makes us human", which I hate (I'm looking at you, The Long Way to a Small, Angry Planet, and also at you, Defy the Stars). Murderbot is not human. Murderbot doesn't want to be human. That means it doesn't necessarily want what the humans want, and that doesn't mean it's evil.
Since Murderbot is not exactly what humans expect when they think about machines, there's a lot of awkwardness between it and the human crew - they do not know how to deal with a machine that looks like a human and almost acts like a human, but it's definitely not one.

Most side characters are forgettable, but there is a side f/f relationship and this is only a novella.

Note: yes, the main character doesn't have a gender and is not interested in sex or romance, but I wouldn't recommend this book as "aro/ace/agender representation" - it's about a robot.
Aromantic/asexual/agender people are real and definitely human.

All Systems Red has a distinct plot and likeable secondary characters, but for me its main failing is the protagonist Murderbot.

Murderbot's narration is juvenile. Wells hardly provides any information about why Units are manufactured the way--part organic, part robotic--and my question at the end was, why bother with the expensive organic parts and consciousness that needs to be overridden by modules when it would be objectively cheaper to use robots? As the only substantially developed science fiction element of the story, I wanted a lot more information. How did it became ubiquitous to manufacture and use these entities with the potential for free will? Potentially a question that will be explored in the sequels, but not one I will stick around to find out the answer to.

Murderbot's main traits are being conflicted about its identity as half organic/half mechanical, and watching a lot of television. Specifically, over 35,000 hours or close to four years since it hacked its government module...yet it has a startling lack of identity for a unit that sought, and has had, autonomy for that long. Additionally, no basis of comparison for previous missions was provided. Although it's implied that this is the first time the humans have considered Murderbot to be a person, I wanted it to be more clear about what had changed with this mission. At 150 pages, All Systems Red didn't have space to provide background that would have helped me be more invested.

The plot works! But I also didn't find myself surprised by anything that happened -- the antagonists are predictable and quickly dealt with, and there are no real consequences for the crew. And then, a small pet peeve of mine: Murderbot is nearly killed/off-lined multiple times...for such a short book, that's way too much almost dying. The emotional resonance wore off.

I can absolutely see the appeal of this novel for some, but it wasn't for me.

Original review: Ok, now THIS is how you write a novella. Quickly detailed worldbuilding without infodumping, a fast plot, and an engaging narrator.

This was way more heavily sci-fi than I normally read (spaceships, bots, foreign planets), but the main character (a self-aware security bot who's addicted to soaps) was so likeable that it was impossible for me to not enjoy the story.

Subtracting a star because I felt like I wasn't able to clearly tell apart all of the human characters (though that may have been an intentional writing choice, meant to mimic the narrator's own feelings toward the humans). I knew the names, but couldn't remember which was which except for a couple of main ones. I also felt like the ending felt a bit abrupt....but there are sequels.

I'll definitely be reading more in this series.

He's technically able to do anything he wants but decides to keep helping his crew and not, you know, murder them. This is probably for the best because thing start getting very strange on this alien planet and something definitely isn't right. This is the first in a planned series of books I will voraciously be following. Great stuff.

date: People always describe this as a quirky book and often it doesn't really come across as a serious contribution to SF literature in reviews, which is a shame. Especially since this is the first time reading a novella series that I read a book of it and it didn't feel too short. This worked great as its own story, I also really like the characters and how Martha Wells plays a little with Science Fiction tropes along the way. I understand why so many people find Murderbot relatable, but it's fascinating how this type of character could have easily been written as unlikable. There are some funny lines, but you don't have to like humorous books to enjoy this.

Short and punchy but thought-provoking, All Systems Red is the first novella in the Murderbot Diaries series by Martha Wells, featuring the titular Murderbot as the protagonist. It‚Äôs a mystery-adventure set in deep space, with cool tech and a complex, interesting world. Also, much to my enjoyment, it explored ideas I love to see in scifi: what it means to be a person and how technology impacts society.

The point-of-view character and protagonist, a corporation-owned security robot, gave itself its name after the company‚Äôs cheap parts led to a hardware malfunction and, ultimately, a murderous rampage on the part of Murderbot. Not wanting to be subjected to catastrophic parts failures again, it hacked its own Governor Module and gave itself free will. What does Murderbot want to do now that it doesn‚Äôt explicitly have to obey company and client orders? Well, watch a whole lot of space soap operas and download massive amounts of data from entertainment feeds, that‚Äôs what:


I could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don't know, a little under 35,00 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.


#relatable.

(Not the murder part, but like...I feel you, Murderbot. Sometimes a sentient being just wants to be left alone and devour some entertainment, y‚Äôknow?)

(I want to add that I‚Äôm referring to Murderbot as ‚Äúit‚Äù because that seems like the pronoun it prefers, and it doesn‚Äôt identify with any gender. If that ever changes in later novellas or the upcoming novel, I‚Äôll add another note to this!)

I want to emphasize that I love that Murderbot explicity doesn‚Äôt want to be human. Not in a ‚Äúew, humans are gross‚Äù kind of way, but in a ‚ÄúI am a different form of life and that is perfectly fine, even if I myself haven‚Äôt exactly figured out what I want to be‚Äù sort of way. It‚Äôs great and Murderbot is great and you should read this. Yes, you. Please.

The setup for this novella is already interesting on its own: it‚Äôs kind of unsettlingly similar to our current situation with late-stage capitalism, just worse, with more advanced technology, and in space. It‚Äôs not completely doom and gloom, though; while mega-corporations are omnipresent and even have their own corporate states, they‚Äôre not all-powerful. There are other free states and ways of living. (Speaking of, the diversity rep in the novel is great, with many characters mentioning having multiple partners/same gender partners, and none of the humans I can recall as being white.) So while the world is still often a shitty place in both large and small ways, it‚Äôs not hopelessly bleak. In that way, the setting and plot provide an interesting layer of commentary on corporate motivations and how people move around and within money-hungry power structures.

While the plot of this novella is short, it‚Äôs entertaining and to the point. We have just enough time to take a walk in Murderbot‚Äôs shoes, seeing the world through its sardonic point of view, while also seeing how its human crew reacts to its sentience. There‚Äôs enough space for the plot and characters to create and release tension around ideas of humanity and free will without the dialogue getting esoteric or the narration getting info-dumpy. The story sticks around just long enough to make you ready to read the next novella right away.

Before I try to wrap this up: a nod (or like, many many nods) to Kevin R. Free, the audiobook narrator/reader. I‚Äôve listened to one other novella he‚Äôs narrated, The Sorcerer of the Wildeeps, and his voice and inflection in both of these works of his that I‚Äôve listened to are absolutely wonderful. I can‚Äôt imagine Murderbot sounding any other way in my head now. (Speaking of which, my library needs to get the audiobook for the next ones in the series ASAP.)

I can‚Äôt think of a good way to end this review, if I‚Äôm being honest. In the process of writing this, I actually bumped my rating up from 4 to 4.5, rounded up to a 5. I just liked it that much, and it used the novella format exceptionally well to tell its story. I highly recommend checking it out if you have the chance.

Winner of the 2017 Nebula Award for Best Novella, All Systems Red is one of those books that was impossible to ignore with its buzz being almost omnipresent since its release. The praise it was getting was unquestionable and its blurb alone had me hooked and utterly curious to find out what all the fuzz was about. Dying to try novellas again, this series seemed like the perfect re-entry point for me. I mean, how could anything go wrong with an android called a ‚ÄúMurderbot‚Äù being the main character? In the end, there‚Äôs no denying that this turned out to be addictive and engaging. The journey of this Murderbot is one that develops steadily with a satisfying balance between action and humour.

What exactly is All Systems Red about though? This is the story of a SecUnit tasked to protect a team of scientists on their expedition in dangerous fields. Unlike other androids, this one however hacked its governor module (the very component that allows humans to control them) and successfully got its hands on what we would call ‚Äúfree will‚Äù. Instead of turning rampant or escaping its faith as a SecUnit, this android has assigned itself the purpose of protecting its clients at all cost. Remaining inconspicuous among the team is however a struggle, but whenever it can, it will find ways to avoid contact and find peace in isolation. It‚Äôs when things go awry with another crew of scientists that this android and its clients find themselves looking for answers, but also pernicious trouble, with unknown danger staring right back at them.

For a first installment in The Murderbot Diaries series, All Systems Red does a comprehensive portrayal of artificial intelligence in ways that have rarely been conducted in the past. Instead of having a robot who wants to become human, we find ourselves in front of one that is human. Its personality is incredibly relatable and far more human than some of us could ever be, but this Murderbot only wishes to be left alone in its introverted lifestyle. Stuck trying to hide its true self from a crew of scientists who would never truly understand it, it finds satisfaction in accomplishing its role as a Company-supplied security android in order to stay away from any potential trouble that the knowledge of its free will would have upon it.

Interestingly enough, this Murderbot is never referred to as a male or a female throughout the story. While I saw it as a woman all along, I was far too often able to connect myself to its most deepest desires (i.e. being left alone to enjoy some space soap opera). Martha Wells‚Äô writing style also proves to be impeccable in All Systems Red and effortlessly manages to give this android a voice of its own. Without the focus on its gender, she was able to bring the reader to explore subtler details that helped further accentuate the android‚Äôs peculiar situation in a world of humans that only sees things from their own selfish position.

All Systems Red is a fascinating novella that follows an introverted android in its quest to embrace its true-self while trying to respect its purposes as a Murderbot. What it will come to realize will however force it to embark on an adventure that it might not ever be ready for, as both its purpose and its rights as an android with free will are tested.

Thank you to Raincoast Books and Tor.com / Tom Doherty Associates for sending me a copy for review!

Yours truly,

All System Red if u were to sum it up with few words it would be a short but fun ride.

This will be a short review as it only took basically a day to finish this novella. Plus, I wouldn't be quite harsh on it as I have a different expectation of a just above 30k novella compared to like 100k - 400k novel. For what its intents to achieve I think Murderbot does its job well, which is liking the named protagonist.

Edit: I should rephrase I don't think I gave Martha Wells enough credit but Murderbot, not just a likable protagonist. I think She does a good job of fleshing him out. Showcasing AI in a unique perspective. The Shy aspect of Murderbot is pretty great, it does feel distinct.

As from the introduction it states


‚Äú I COULD HAVE BECOME a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don‚Äôt know, a little under 35,000 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.‚Äù



Which I mean is a great hook to a series, the status quo of series of this nature already bent. I do think booktube has given this novella or series (well I should read the rest to see if that is true) but a false expectation. This is nothing deep or found thought-provoking which contrast to what I been reading recently is not a bad thing. It delivers on it being a fun adventure all around. Besides the opening paragraph, I won‚Äôt give anything else regarding the plot as it probably spoils half this novella. The plot in general nothing to hit home about which is fine. The characters voices are not that distinct not even about being well fleshed out as you got like 3-4 humans and 30k word count, you got to be realistic in terms of priorities. Just hoped voices were a bit more distinct. The prose well does its job in its first-person, especially at the end its well contextualised. They some distance to the writing style which is quite clear and to the point which reflects on the character well enough. The Worldbuilding I don‚Äôt have too many thoughts on but for a novella and what it sets out I am not going to be critical about that aspect, plus murderbot doesn‚Äôt give a shit about the world so that‚Äôs why we don‚Äôt know too much. However, I do like the information they gave about the murderbot units.


‚ÄúDid I mean a cilia or was that something else? They don‚Äôt give murderbots decent education modules on anything except murdering, and even those are the cheap versions.‚Äù


Cheaply made been a reoccurring thing from the beginning of the novella. But what is interesting is the organic material aspect. All featuring the same generic face as you would in an RPG. Also, the emotional side of Murderbot leaves me curious about certain aspects of the world. I do think the sequels will be better just considering how the ending of this book has opened certain things where I am unsure where it's heading.

In Conclusion, this is no outstanding novella or whatever its just some lighthearted fun entertainment that u can consume within 2-4 hrs max. I do think the concept of murderbot is cooler than what actually displayed like the opening lines are great, but I definitely wait and see; interested in continuing the adventure in the future.

6/10

Changing my score for this novella still judging it as a novella and not a novel. But more I think about it and what you can do in small fiction, unsure if I can confidently give it a 6.5 so yeah it's now 6/10

A story set on a distant planet and focusing on some kind of robot (or SecUnit) in charge of security for a team of scientists just couldn‚Äôt go wrong. I actually started reading this novella without reading anything about it. I was expecting a bit more action or violence since the series has the word ‚ÄúMurderbot‚Äù in it, which (surprisingly) led me to believe there would be lots of murder. Still, I was nicely surprised when I dived in a story that really focuses on what‚Äôs happening inside the main character‚Äôs head and the relationship (or absence of) between him and the other characters.

The first page (yes it‚Äôs a first page, I set the font size very large haha) did the trick, I was sold:
‚ÄúI could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As an heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.‚Äù

The team has a number of scientists and at first I was not motivated to try and remember everyone‚Äôs name and just didn‚Äôt make any effort for this. I still ended up knowing a little bit of info about all of them and having no difficulty whatsoever to know who was who. Just like the SecUnit, I didn‚Äôt care about them and ended up warming up to them in the course of the story.

‚ÄúThat sounded like a great plan, in that it didn‚Äôt involve me.‚Äù

The main character is some kind of robot, or man-machine who pirated itself (it uses this pronoun so I'll be using it as well) and enjoys being alone, watching any kind of entertainment. What‚Äôs not to love about this? This SecUnit is also super relaxed, blas√© and snarky, bored about everything, just getting on with life and what it has to do to be left alone. Except when it has to interact with humans, then it is the most awkward of all the SecUnits. To avoid interacting with the humans it works with, he keeps its armor and helmet on at all times. That made me think of the kids who wear a hat or a knit cap on at all time because they feel safer that way.

‚ÄúWhat was I supposed to do, kill all humans because the ones in charge of constructs in the company were callous? Granted, I liked the imaginary people on the entertainment feed way more than I liked the real ones, but you can‚Äôt have one without the other.‚Äù

I laughed, I giggled, and I was on the edge of my seat. The way All Systems Red was written stroke a chord with me and it left me deeply content, thankful for such a nice story. Even while writing this review and rereading all the passages I had highlighted (or rather, the PAGES), I was laughing and hurting that I couldn‚Äôt quote everything or even hand this novella to everyone just like that.

This novella really left me with a warm feeling. I cannot wait to read more on this Murderbot Series. This one and Killing Gravity are my favourite novellas from 2017 so far! All Systems Red was only 87 pages on my ereader but it didn‚Äôt felt too short at all. It left me wanting more, but I don‚Äôt think it lacked of anything. I really need to take a look at the other stories Martha Wells has written because I loved everything here!

Everything about this book was completely out of my comfort zone and not at all what I would gravitate towards, but I enjoyed it so much. The protagonist was more endearing than most other protagonists I've read, despite being part-robot. The storytelling was solid, and the plot was such a breath of fresh air. This is a 4 to 4.5* read for me, with the only thing stopping it from being a 5* simply being that I zoned out sometimes during the more sci-fi-ish bits, which was sometimes quite dense for a sci-fi layperson like me.

This is a pretty short book, but it took me probably more than half of it to figure out exactly what was going on in terms of the world, the plot, and even just the names for everything (I'm just not used to so much sci-fi and tech jargon in my books). Despite that, the book still managed to be engaging enough almost right from the start, primarily due to the the protagonist's engaging voice - it might be a Murderbot, but it's also just a really shy, introverted entity that just wants to hide behind its opaque face shield thing all day, watch the amazing amount of TV serials it's downloaded, and not have to talk to humans, especially not about its feelings. Honestly, kind of relatable.

Murderbot (it doesn't really have an actual name, so we'll just call it that) is contracted out to a group of scientists and explorers, presumably in some spacefaring civilisation. It's actually a SecUnit (a security unit) that is rented out to these expeditions to protect people from hostile alien lifeforms (or other humans, I suppose). We kinda sorta get to know the scientists in Murderbot's group and they play a big role in the actual plot of this particular story, but the book being as short as it is means that we don't get the time to actually know these characters very well. While I'd love to hear more of them in the subsequent instalments, the main attraction of the story really is Murderbot and its perspective so I wouldn't say this at all detracts from the beauty of the book.

The group and Murderbot discover another expedition of scientists brutally murdered, and then it's a rollercoaster ride from there as they try to figure out who's behind that massacre before the culprits catch up with them to do the same.

What I particularly liked about the storytelling is that, even though we get the events from Murderbot's perspective, we can't help also feeling a little distrustful of Murderbot and wondering if it might be an unreliable narrator. Does that mean I'm siding with the humans over the non-human, even though we are seeing the story through the latter's eyes? What makes Murderbot, who is only part-robot with "organic parts" (i.e. human bits, since it has an actual face and other human organs, which it is able to regenerate when injured or even regrow when it's completely blasted off), different from the augmented humans in this story, when both of them are able to access feeds and information systems presumably via their brains alone? Tl;dr this is a sci-fi story but I find that it made me ask a lot of pretty interesting questions about the nature of robots and artificial intelligence, especially when juxtaposed with human emotions. And the book didn't bald-facedly ask those questions, just set things up so that readers might be provoked into asking these for themselves. That's damn good writing there.

Overall, highly recommended for anyone, especially if you're a sci-fi fan. But even if you're like me and not familiar with sci-fi at all, this still remains a great read.

Someone has it in for the team, and it is the Murderbot‚Äôs job to defend the people they refer to as ‚Äúmy humans.‚Äù But how can Murderbot find out who the killer it, or even who they (Murderbot) are, without being found out themself?

This was a sweet novella, but I think my expectations may have been too high due to all the buzz. Murderbot was a lovable character and I liked most of the humans working on the team. Reread 2023: The story is just as I remembered. Socially awkward robot, check! Desire to ignore the job and watch dramas, check! Pretty quick to the action, check! On to the next novella? Check!

------------

All Systems Red is the first in a series of novellas titled The Murderbot Diaries by Martha Wells. Based on that kind of title who would have expected a story about a security robot that hacks it's own governing module so can watch tv all day instead of doing its job? I know I didn't. And boy was this story great fun.

Sometime in the future, the Company approves and supplies all planetary missions. As standard procedure all teams are accompanied by Company provided security androids, called SecUnits, a regulatory 1 android per 10 humans. On a distant planet, a research team is conducting surveys of the surface. Sure, there have been strange computer glitches from time to time, all perfectly normal considering programming contracts tend to go to the lowest bidder. That is right up until a neighboring mission goes dark and the scientists are determined to find out what happened.

Clocking in at just over 150 pages, Wells does an impressive job. The plot takes off immediately, with the researchers and Murderbot finding themselves in a highly dangerous situation they never expected. On top of that she weaves in great characterization for Murderbot. Being an android who is finds dealing with humans uncomfortable and slightly annoying, preferring instead just watch them on tv, it's highly relatable to anyone who was an awkward teen growing up or just on those days when you'd rather not deal with people. Though Murderbot tries to come across as apathetic, I think it does care underneath it all. The downside to having such limited space is the rest of the characters aren't nearly so fleshed out. That's ok though since this is Murderbot's story.

Well written and entertaining, this was a satisfying short read.

I liked the humor a lot. It's not so much laugh out loud funny as it is clever/wry. That suits me just fine.

I also really like the humans in this book. The interaction between Murderbot and his humans was what really moved this story rather than the plot. I feel like the crisis could have almost been anything and it wouldn't have mattered.

I'm not rushing out to pick up Artificial Condition right away due to it being a novella instead of novel, but it's on my wish list and I'm sure I'll get around to it eventually.

And she‚Äôs like: ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs a bot! The story is told in the first person from the perspective of a bot. So the narrator is an anti-social, non-human construct. The characters have no personality to you because they have no personality to the bot that‚Äôs telling you the story.‚Äù My mouth snapped shut. Silence. I‚Äôm thinking: holy shit. I had to sit down. She was right. Suddenly this book that I hated unto vituperation struck me as soaring genius. Then I started thinking about the courage it took Wells as a writer to intentionally write something shitty in order to faithfully reflect the perspective of a character. OMG. I forgot to step back is what happened. I‚Äôve felt incensed like this about a piece of literature before, but in that case I paused and asked myself: Hey, was that on purpose, maybe? And when I realized the offending particulars were indeed by design, I understood the trick of the story. I didn‚Äôt ask that question this time. There is some prejudice in me against genre lit, I think. Without that prejudice I would have taken a breath and thought it through. I need to address this blind spot. Schooled by Martha Wells (and my wife). Five stars for bravery. Three stars in general. Four solid stars.

Oh, Avatar meets Asimov meets wifi. That‚Äôs how I sum it up.

When you read a book in one sitting, you know it's good. All Systems Red, by Martha Wells, is the first book in The Murderbot Diaries - a campy and schlocky sounding series name. I read it for a quick science fiction hit, and came away quite surprised, and excited to continue the series. Wells has packed a slim and short science fiction novella with lots of heart, detail and style. The book follows Murderbot - self titled name of a rogue security android who has hacked it own governing module in order to think freely. It spends most of its time watching entertainment serials while it pretends to continue its role - providing security for surveying teams on alien worlds. The job is mostly boring, and Murderbot enjoys the downtime, as well as its own crippling social anxiety, and hides behind its robotic side to avoid human contact. However, when its current job goes dangerous, and a conspiracy begins to form, Murderbot feels compelled to protect its current human employers.

The book is simple in many ways - the story is straightforward, for example, and most of the characters outside Murderbot are only minimal factors. Even so, so much story, character and heart is packed into Muderbot and its thought process. The setting and world building are also fantastic. This is my favourite part of science fiction. I love an author that can pack in style and substance, and build a world that I can lose myself in. Wells has done a fabulous job, and in hundreds of pages less than most authors. This book is a fun read. It's quick, stylistic, and a good hit of science fiction. An easy recommendation from me, and certainly the best science fiction novel I have read in a while.

The mystery here got me and I want to know what's going on with those corporate entities and where this is all going. The team of humans in Murderbot's charge had a good showing here too and I was really glad they survived. Among all my other burning questions: What's next on RaFOSM? To make a hard-boiled story work, against any background, you need two things: a first-person narrator with a distinctive, preferable world-weary and cynical, voice, and a good mystery. This first "Murderbot" novella is therefore a working hard-boiled story. Someone has slaughtered the scientists at one planetary survey base, and the inhabitants of the other, with their security robot (aka the titular Murderbot), have to figure out who and why, while also trying to stay alive. Murderbot's unexpected musings on humanity, the society that created him, and the nature of free will provide the philosophical and thematic base of the story, but this is a locked-room (or base) mystery with a corking good supporting cast and a suspenseful ending. It bodes well for the rest of the series.

Murderbot is so me! Haha. In the sense that 9 out of 10 times I would rather waste time binge watching Fringe than to interact with humans, and that work is sometimes tedious and gets so dull or repetitive that I need to have my favorite movies playing in the background to keep me entertained but at the same time I'm tied to this feeling that I can't step away from my job because RESPONSIBILITIES ya know. I just really love this ‚Äúbot person‚Äù main character who is truly relatable with its existential bot angst.

While the plot itself is not that mysterious and rather straightforward, it generated enough tension for me to care and worry about the fate of Murderbot and the humans under its care. However, what I found so brilliant about this book is the author's portrayal of a cyborg construct that, while logical in its approach to doing its job, behaves emotionally very much like a traumatized human child.

I mean think about it. This is a bot with some clone-tech-generated organic parts basically making it partly human, that was created essentially to kill, had spent the entirety of its life killing other beings, and whose governor module became corrupted so it went rogue and committed mass murder. After which, it was reformatted and brought back to service another security contract. This is the human equivalent of sending a person to serve in multiple wars and exposing them to the trauma of having to extinguish multiple lives while constantly being exposed to the threat of being killed yourself‚Ä¶ and then while you're still carrying all that PTSD you are placed again in a similar situation that can very well trigger your past trauma. No wonder it is self-hating and calls itself Murderbot. (NB: psychological analyses of war veterans have documented that committing violence can be as traumatizing and dehumanizing as being violated, at least in the cases of soldiers who felt like they had no choice but to carry out instructions and do whatever was necessary to survive the battlefield.)

On top of that, because it wasn't that long ago that its governor module was hacked, Murderbot is still emotionally either a child or a young teenager who is grappling with its existence as an actual sentient entity with its own free will. It never experienced a childhood, so it never got itself gradually socialized to humans or other sentient beings under the guidance of caring adults, therefore it found face-to-face human interaction awkward and anxiety-inducing. On this contract, with the PreservationAux team, Murderbot is essentially navigating an awkward high school phase while possibly still at the emotional maturity of a kindergartner. The fact that it found a comforting parental figure in Dr Mensah is also interesting. The different ways that the human crew members responded to Murderbot after they've seen it without armor, looking ‚Äúnormal‚Äù aka humanlike, were very well-written. The general impulse in everyone EXCEPT the sole augmented human in the group was to treat Murderbot as a person ‚Äì that irony is definitely not lost on me. It also triggered several conversations among the humans whether it's morally right to keep bots working for humans without giving the bots a choice about it. Of course, when Murderbot was dragged into such conversations it was excruciatingly painful for it to contemplate its place in the general scheme of things. It most definitely wasn't ready for that conversation yet as it was only just beginning to explore what existing as a person even means.

I truly enjoyed this imaginative, speculative exploration of what being a newly self-aware robot might be like. There exist many questions underneath this novella: questions of sentience, free will, slavery, self-identity, self-hatred, discrimination, social inequality, the military industrial complex, etc. Looking forward to binge reading the entire series!
